reviewText:
After the 100% completion I can say that:
When it comes to visual differences the Definitive Edition features better lighting, character models and textures, some improved world textures, more depth of field, smoke, smoother reflections and visual effects. In short, the game feels more organic.

Now you have more people and cars on the screen. I've noticed new faces, different outfits and generally better looks.

The keyboard keys were remapped to more standard layout. Notable changes:
-RMB to E (entering cars, countering).
-Space to L.Shift (sprint and parkour).
-RMB now is used for lock-on.

The game mechanics are mostly the same. HUD has been slightly revamped, making elements sharper, smaller. Phone's front and UI has been changed completely. Most of the icons have been changed. Main menu has activity feed now and you can switch between social hub entries without the need to wait until they load.

The car traffic AI is okay-ish, heavy trucks still scratch the walls on turns, but I've noticed that the AI sometimes keeps crashing into my parked cars. Car physics are semi-buggy. There have been cases of weird spawns and semi floating vehicles.

Pedestrian AI needs a bit of polishing. I've experienced bunch of harmless / hilarious bugs and glitches:
-Some individuals keep walking into other people as if they were walking into a wall.
-Friendly AI had problems entering my car / locating door when needed.
-Some thugs were levitating for a brief moment.
-Panicking thugs tried to escape, got in a car and kept driving into a wall (they try to back off, but still hit the exact same spot).
-Enemy reinforcements sometimes get stuck between cars or they keep looking at you from afar.
-Random guy upstairs in Club Bam Bam went through the floor and landed on the ground floor like it was nothing.
-Some pedestrian animations keep overwriting themselves (loop too early) and end up looking like they're having a stroke.
-Sometimes people get spawned above the water.
-Some people get stuck in walls.

I've also noticed some audio issues. Sometimes some sound effects aren't played or they randomly appear / disappear. Seems like some audio bits also get either delayed or overlap (especially noticeable if happens during dialogues). Even had 2 radio tracks playing at the same time.
I'd like to point out that camera needs tweaking too. Sometimes it doesn't center well, stucks in things or points at wrong angles, has weird sensivity. Especially noticable in action hijacks.
I didn't experience these issues in original patched SD.

The DLC content is nicely implemented into the main game. You do not get instant access to the items (which would ruin the experience and challenge like in the original SD), instead you can access them in shops (the clothes guy says wacky lines about individual sets), so in-game currency has extra use now. The NANP and YOS side stories are available directly at the main menu, no need to switch between them. The red envelopes are now scattered all around the map and can be found in semi-hidden places. Notable difference: most of the DLC related side missions can only be played once, not including Zodiac island.

SWAT Pack DLC's unlimited side missions were turned into Cop Job". No need to travel in a HKPD vehicles
date: the missions are marked separately on your map and unlock based on your progression. Possible scenarios (possible spoilers):\n-You raid
recommended: beat up and arrest street gangs while having a bunch of officers as a backup.\n-You're given a vehicle and have to ram the escaping suspect's car
hoursPlayed:
then arrest him.
-You respond to store shootouts and neutralize thugs.
-Sharpshooting / one shot kill the thug without harming the hostage.

There are also some modified individual side missions (possible spoilers):
-"High Speed". Imagine Need for Speed: Hot Pursuit. You've given a police car and your goal is to shutdown a race by slamming into racer cars.
-Modified "Death by a Thousand Cuts". Arena fighting with a golden meat cleaver. Enemies have poisoned weapons and your goal is to survive and kill 30 enemies.  it's quite hardcore
voteText:
especially if you haven't upgraded anything.
-Modified "Shaolin Showdown". Defeat 40 monks. Up to 30 on screen.

The optimization is even better than in the original. Playable on higher resolutions with less performance hits.
Notable difference: you can Alt+Tab freely. The game doesn't go into windowed mode anymore and stays in full screen
helpfulPercent:
there's no need to change options back every time (which was extremely annoying).

Final verdict:
Worth if you've never (for some reason) played the game before.
Otherwise for fans that enjoyed the game.
PS. Needs a lot of patching. The bugs add up even if they're semi harmless.

I may update this review if we discover some new "facts"."

reviewText:
What is it?A story-driven action adventure set in a gorgeously recreated Hong Kong setting (a mix of various Hong Kong sectors fairly accurately recreated).  The game is based on real events (though names have been changed).  You are Wei Shen, and you lead a double life as a Triad gang member and an undercover cop - so you will be playing both sides of the story.  It is Wei's job to bring down the Sun On Yee gang (a tweaked name of the real-life 'Sun Yee On') from the inside, and so he must find a way in, and get people to trust him.  Soon, Wei starts to feel divided loyalties as he gets in deeper and deeper.  The main storyline is linear but the plot is fast-paced and entertaining.  There are masses of side missions that fit in with the plot very well and you can choose when and if to play these.

Sleeping Dogs contains all the usual open-world elements we love: a gorgeously atmospheric and thriving city densely populated with people and traffic, great ambience (especially the night market), vehicles to unlock and drive (or simply steal), USEFUL collectibles that either upgrade your health and strength, or your bank balance!

Is it easy to play?Very.  The driving and parkour elements are simple and responsive and the martial arts moves are only taught gradually and are not overly complex, though you might find yourself scribbling down a few moves as there are ultimately 12 to remember!  The game's tuition system spreads your learnt moves gradually through the game using a novel system of returning to Wei's former Kung Fu school.  For exchange of each school's missing trophies, you will be taught a new move and given some non-aggressive adversaries to practise it on.  It works very well.  As for weapons combat, I personally found it easier to switch to mouse for aiming, but the game switches seamlessly between controllers while playing.  The only negative aspect is the sometimes-uncontrollable camera angles after reversing a vehicle.  The camera is too slow to face forward, meaning you often start driving blindly.  Other than this, everything is great.

RequirementsRegarding game requirements, you really will need to pay attention to those because this is a heavy game graphically.  There is some stutter in the cut-scenes regardless of GPU but the cut-scenes are only occasional.  You will benefit greatly from a gamepad.  This is not the sort of game for people who have a 'delicate' audience in the room as there is a lot of 'colourful' language and such.    If you're a female gamer, you'll probably cringe at some of the lines spoken by some women (some are really bad!) - but not enough to kill enjoyment of the game.

Is it worth upgrading from the original?If you enjoyed the game enough that you'd likely play it through again, then I'd say yes.  It looked great before but there are a plethora of improvements: denser NPCs and traffic, heaps more variety in shop signs, lots more lit signs, beautiful environment effects, super-realistic road and building textures and improved controls.  A few bugs in the original game have been fixed, and all the cars, outfits, apartments and cash DLC is no longer automatically awarded to you at the beginning of the game (a problem with the original version, leaving players with nothing further to play for).  The only caution is that, if your PC struggled a bit with the original, it will struggle more with this version given that it is a much heavier game for your GPU.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is a nice blend of several different game genres, and while none of them are anything new or groundbreaking, everything generally played well. The original (non-definitive) version is one of the few games I have 100% completion on in my steam library.

Since you can read up on pretty much any review for the actual game, I thought I'd focus on what's new for this re-release.

The biggest improvement probably went into how the dlc was handled. Every single dlc (with the exception of the top dog booster packs) is now included, and rather than just dumping them all on you at once, they were all was integrated into the game a little better, unlocking a few pieces from each as you progress through the story. While some of the changes are minor, like a new vendor in the night market who sells some of the dlc costumes, they actually went back and tweaked a few of them to flow better. For example, the Shaolin Showdown" side mission is no longer an endless arena where you fight until you die
date: but now has you running to several locations fighting smaller groups of enemies
recommended: eventually climaxing into one of the largest melee fights in the entire game. The Swat dlc missions were also changed into individual "Cop missions" that feel like they have a little more variety now and unlock over time instead of all at once. In fact
hoursPlayed: almost every mission got some sort of small tweak to it. However
voteText: Nightmare in North Point and Year of the Snake are still separate standalone stories that don't take your progress in the main story into account (though they both still unlock a few bonus items for the story when completed).\n\nThe graphics also got a bit of an upgrade
helpfulPercent: though it's not immediately obvious because the original PC game was already a big improvement over the 360/ps3 versions. Mostly
votesHelpful: everything now has even higher-resolution textures
votesTotal: and there are some new effects like fog in the streets
votesFunny: remodeled skin and hair for most characters that looks great in cutscenes
commentsCount: more dense vehicle and pedestrian traffic
column16: and some new outdoor effects. In particular
column17: the new rain effect (and the puddles it leaves on the street) looks fantastic.\n\nIf you never played Sleeping Dogs
column18: you really owe it to yourself to pick up this re-release
column19: as it fixes some of the flaws of the original and includes all the dlc. However
column20: if you already played the original and most of its dlc
column21: you should probably skip this. Improvements and dlc aside
column22: there is no new content (mission or story-wise) whatsoever."

reviewText:
Because this is the same exact game as Sleeping dogs, my review for this game is also the same copy pasted text except now it's in 1080p high definition letters.
Seriously if you own the original game and all the DLC's do not buy this one. If you don't own this game, buy it, it's amazing.

Wonderful game. Looks like GTA and Yakuza had a child and itâ€™s turned out to be awesome.
Sleeping dogs owns GTA4 in every way. I was forcing myself to finish GTA4 and enjoyed Sleeping dogs twice (on PS3 and after couple of years on Steam) and even collected all the achievements.
Firstly the graphics are much better, GTA4 looks like crap and sleeping dogs looks great and when itâ€™s start to rain it looks amazing. Sleeping dogs runs much MUCH better too while GTA4 is barely playable and bad looking even on high end machines.
The gameplay is much more fun than broken GTA4, where controls are pathetic, shooting is frustrating, cars are bouncing, etc. This is not existent in Sleeping dogs. Controls are really good except for some rare camera issues. Driving is fun, especially shooting while driving and hijacking. And shooting mechanics is great, itâ€™s easy to target the enemy, shoot him in the head, hide behind cover or disarm the enemy.
The fighting system, is something like Yakuza. There are some combos which you learn by levelling up, you can use environment and knives, cleavers or even umbrellas, purses and my favourite â€“ a fish to kill people.
Side missions are not boring unlike in some other games, most of them are different every time. Catching the thieves, throwing out the drunks from the shop, collecting debts, stealing cars or find the lady in a carâ€™s trunk and free her only to find out that itâ€™s some sexual game and she was waiting for her husband to find her, not you.
The story is good too. As undercover cop you must infiltrate the triad and bring them down. So you play as a cop and as a gangster depending on the mission. Sometimes itâ€™s just driving, sometimes fighting or some bloody shootout.
Oh and the game have radio with a different genre of music. My favourite is roadrunner records station. It has such bands like Machine head, Dream theatre, Soulfly and Trivium. Itâ€™s really fun to kick some teeth while Fear factoryâ€™s edgecrusher is playing :)
The only downside of this game for me is that it lacks activities. After playing Yakuza games which has a bunch of activities I want more of them in other games too. The only activities are â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ fights, races and mah-jong. Because of this Iâ€™m giving this game 9/10 :)

reviewText:
I only bought this game, because I live in Shanghai and I thought it would be nice to play a GTA-like game in an environment I'm familiar with. The city in this game is Hong Kong only in name. The city itself does not look like Hong Kong at all (I travel to HK a lot so I would know), so this might as well be Shanghai.
The attention to detail in this game is mind blowing. I mean, sure the game elements (story, gameplay, fighting, racing, etc) are fine and entertaining, but what I really like the most about this game are the people. The main characters and especially the people on the street are so authentic and believable! I just love it!
From obvious chanting of the street vendors to the not so obvious nose drilling sound before spitting, loud chewing with open mouth or the way people talk (even if translated into English). This is just my personal opinion of the game. If you are Chinese or if you have visited Hong Kong/Shanghai, get this game and have a good time! But since there's a better choice (GTAV), get this game when it's on sale. By now the full price is not worth it.

reviewText: Look at Watch Dogs. Now at this game. Now back to Watch Dogs. Now back to this game. Sadly Watch Dogs aren't nearly as well-optimized, while offering marginally (very marginally) better graphical fidelity. Also Watch Dogs doesn't have an amazingly authentic city of Hong Kong with TONS of cultural education content. Neither does it have an interesting unique combat system, phenomenal voice acting, great satisfying driving with action hijacking, actually meaningful and clever hacking minigame (ironic, right?), a lot of variety in mission types and gameplay and a good storyline with actual emotions and some seriously shocking scenes.\n\nSleeping Dogs Definitive edition is definitely a definitive Open World Action game in a well-defined location, with a defiant for the genre, yet great combat system and the very definition of what a GTA-style game should be. Definitely. Incredible game, as is usually the case with Square Enix-published games. EFG have delivered in full. Wholeheartedly recommend.

The game is a nicely polished version of the original. Mostly for fans of the original game who want to up their experience a little or for those who want all the DLC for a decent price. Either way, fantastic game made better.

reviewText:
I had Wei too much fun playing through this game again.

It's like GTA IV; with a dash of Jet Li's lighting fast kicks. The charm and comedy of Jackie Chan in his prime. The visceral brutality of Tony Jaa. With a huge dose of Bruce Lee's Enter the Dragon, and a sprinkle of Andy Lau's The Election. And you have Sleeping Dogs.

Fast-paced, and meatier than two pork buns -- if you haven't played this, you've dishonored your Sifu. You should be ashamed.

9.8 Pok Gai's out of 10

reviewText:
+ Impressive graphics; particularly well done are the exterior urban environments
+ Suberb voice-acting
+ Gorgeous weather effects; you can even see steam rising from the pavement after a fresh rain
+ Melee fighting mechanics are satisfying and intuitive
+ Vehicles are well-designed, of sufficient variety, and handle well; the racing missions in this game (not something I'm usually a fan of) are extremely entertaining
+ Freerunning/Parkour (whatever you want to call it) system is simple enough that it adds to the game, but doesn't come off as frustrating
+ The story is engrossing and well-written; not necessarily anything original in content, and there are no significant surprises, but it is delivered so well that you will be very invested with the characters and their relationships (the character developement, too, is very, very  well done)
+ Variety of outfit customization, including several cheeky cameos from other popular franchises

- There are lots of cookie-cutter NPC models
- Plot is linear, in that your choices will not affect the outcome
- Firearm mechanics are easily this game's weakest point; they are clunky and poorly-implemented

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Also, feel free to join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements. Thanks for reading!

You heard the story of Wei Shen! But now, hear it again, only it is prettier now! Like way prettier, also all the hair is all soft and moving and his jackets have little doodads and his clothes have physics that weren't there the first time!

reviewText:
So here is my opinion regarding this game:

Pros:
+Very good combat system
+Nice driving mechanics (for cars, buses and boats)
+Car chases are very fun
+Graphics are good
+Good story
+Likeable characters (you can feel the protagonist anger in you)
+Good experience system
+Destructible environment
+Good voice acting
+Full of content
+DLCs are useful (dat triad car) and some of them add to the character development

Cons
-Some performance issues
-Antialiasing always enabled
-The motorcycle driving isn't very good and it feels like you have no control at higher speeds
-Pedestrians AI is a bit dumb
-Every driver has a tendency to crash in you

Misc
+/- The siren on the police car, when on, doesn't do anything. Drivers don't get out from your way and neither pedestrians. But it looks really nice
+/- A bit hard to maintain your cop score on the main missions, but the experience is easy to gain from side missions.


A well done game. Definetly a 8.5-9/10. I can recommend it.

reviewText:
OH GOD YES
PROS
+good story with interesting characters
+ACTUAL CHARACTER DEVELOPMENT (hard to find in games nowadays)
+super fun melee combat, easy to learn, hard to master, and makes you look like a badass when you master it
+awesome enviromental takedowns that let you use your surroundings to kill enemies (smashing their faces into a phone booth or throwing them into an ice chipper
+nice parkour system that allows use to easily flow from obstacle to obstacle
+super nice graphics, the game looks awesome at night in the rain when all dem effects kick in
+decent driving mechanics, not GTA 5 level but much better than Watch Dogs
+good gunplay, the game doesn't have many gunfights (mainly melee combat) but the few gunfights are pretty solid
+very large map with lots of secrets to uncover (drug dens on top of a building, women being held captive for human trafficking in the sewers, etc.
+â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ ton of content, main story took me 22 hours to beat, lots a side missions as well (street races, gang hideouts to shoot up, detective cases, kareokee for some reason)
+great OST
CONS
-ending was kinding of half-â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, everything was built up for a grand finale but instead of an epic final mission you get a fairly short cutscene...wow
-while the story is good, some characters pop in out of nowhere for a mission or two then are never seen again, gets annoying
-meh perk syrstem, none of the perks really change how you play, just give you little bonuses here and their (save for the melee combat tree)
-despite the kickas OST, the radio music is meh
-the game has street races, yet no way to customize cars...wut?

VERDICT
Great open world crime drama, fun and engaging combat and only a few small nitpicks, 100% reccomend this at full price

reviewText: Sleeping Dogs the Definitive Edition is a great rebranding of the original game. It updates the parkour and combat system with slightly new controls and in my opinion more response from the original. The driving has been improved by alot the only thing they didnt spiff up a bit was the camera controls while driving which can still be a pain in some situations. As for the textures and update models I will say the graphics haven't been updated that much but the increased models makes the enviroment feel a little bit more immersive. Now for the DLC which I feel is done the right way in this game as opposed to the original where it was all handed to you the second you step into your apartment and you become the endgame badass on mission 2. All the clothing has been added to a Legendary Vendor, police vehicles and equipment is achieved by finishing cop jobs, cars and other clothing is all unlocked via finishing missions/side content and the zodiac tournament. If you haven't yet played this game this is definetly a great buy having the whole game and DLC's in one with update mechanics and improved code for a much more stable playing experience. If you have the original game but not all the DLC's and you were a fan of this game you'll love it all over again. 9/10.

reviewText:
This and Far Cry 3 are probably the 2 games I enjoyed the most in the last 2 or 3 years.
You get to play as Wei Shen, an undercover cop joining the Triads in Hong Kong,
Armed with guns, swords, fish (yes fish), knives and some awesome martial arts skills you get to kick A** around Kong Kong.
I wont get in to the background story as its available on the store page but i will say this is much more than a GTA clone, the gameplay, the story, and especially the location all give this game its own identity.
I visit Far Eastern Asia twice a year and playing this made me want to go back sooner, it also reminded me of home a little with the once British influence of HK, especially the roads and transport.
I didnt want this game to end and when it did I started it again.
10/10 Hoping they make another

reviewText:
Sleeping Dog's is a GTA style action and adventure game set in open-world Hong-Kong, where you take the role of Wei Shen, an undercover cop that infiltrates one of the HK triads Sun On Yee. As game progresses, you gain both Police and Triad XP that provides different perks for each next level. Additionally, you gain face XP that provides additional bonuses and certain collectibles (jade statues) allow you to unlock melee combos in the local martial arts club. The game offers a wide range of various side missions (chase sequences, beat-em up missions, drug busts, dating missions, shooting missions, races) and mini games (â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ (rooster) fights, tournaments, karaoke). In overall, there's a heavy focus on driving and puzzle solving, as well, as hand-to-hand combat. Although, hand-to-hand combat is enjoyable, the driving and puzzle solving starts to get annoying and/or repetitive after a while. It seems, that the game was artificially made longer through driving, lock picking, camera hacking and collectible searching. However, the story is really strong and interesting and you grow attached to the main character and some of the NPCs. The graphics and voice acting are of high level and overall Sleeping Dogs is a fun, action-pumped open-world experience with a nice dose of Hong-Kong action flick influence. But, unfortunately, there are quite a few little faults that pull the game down and, as a result, it offers only a slightly above-the-average experience. Definitely enjoyable, but with more polish it could've been excellent.

PROS:

- Interesting main story missions
- A vast variety of side missions
- A skill tree
- A vast variety of character skins and wide range of vehicle choices
- Great combat mechanics
- Good graphics (although the Definitive Edition is actually not that much of an improvement compared to the Standard Edition)
- Open-world environment that is a simplified and not a very accurate replica of Hong Kong (who cares though?)
- Emma Stone and Lucy Liu as voice actors ;)

CONS:

- Lack of convenient fast-travel options (only taxis that cost money and are not available everywhere and the car valet)
- Dependence on foods and drinks that need constant replenishing for stat boosts
- Annoying driving experience from time to time (narrow streets, intense traffic, AIs suddenly stopping in the middle of the road or changing lanes, camera spins on reverse, exaggerated momentum)
- Sometimes it's hard to find the objective in the street mazes of Hong Kong
- Inaccurate ranged weapons and barely noticeable cross-hairs

MISCELLANEOUS
- Romance is very superficial, it should have had more substance
- Both the Definitive and Standard Edition didn't recognize my Nvidia videocard on Windows 8 and 8.1 and they crashed or freezed on the first loading screen. The forum solutions didn't work. I was able to play Sleeping Dogs only after the upgrade to Windows 10.

My overall rating: 7.5/10

DLCs:

- Nightmare in North Point: imo, the best DLC of them all. A fun combat experience with elements of Chinese folklore. Adds some additional combat mechanics that allows you to fight demons and the blood-craving ghosts.
- The Zodiac Tournament - also a fun story around a fighting tournament in the style of Enter the Dragon
- Year of the Snake - a heavy focus on driving, repetitive side missions. The story is about Wei Shen investigating a terrorist cult. Quite boring.

reviewText: You are a cop
date: I'm an undercover cop. The rules are different"\n\nI think this famous line from the sleeping dogs marketing campaign sums it up well. The games protagonist Wei Shen is as he says in the quote. An undercover cop
recommended: infiltrating the notorious (fictional) Hong Kong Triad the "Sun On Yee." You get to play Wei as he goes deeper and deeper into the Triad lifestyle and organization too try and shut it down from the inside
hoursPlayed:
while trying to keep his loyalties to the police in this sandbox game from Square Enix. The game isnâ€™t perfect but it accomplishes what it wanted to do and is a welcome change of pace in the sandbox genre.

The story begins with Wei Shen working for the police department when he is recruited by the police superintendent to go deep undercover into the Sun On Yee Triad due to his extensive skills and childhood relationships with current members. Wei takes the job on and then the real journey begins. Wei goes through a lot to prove his loyalties to Triad lieutenant Winston along with his childhood friend Jackie. Wei finds that a rival lieutenant is at odds with Winston and it quickly leads to a gang war. Wei has to take extreme actions to prove he is loyal to his Triad which starts to put him at odds with the police. The hole gets deeper and deeper for Wei in a compelling story thatâ€™s well written and well-acted.

The gameplay is pretty standard sandbox fair. It plays pretty much exactly like GTA which it takes obvious inspiration from in almost all aspects of the game. The key difference between the two is the emphasis on melee combat; guns are much more rare in Hong Kong than they are in American based sandbox games. So naturally the melee combat is much more refined than it is in other sandbox games. The melee combat plays almost identical to the "Batman Arkham" series
voteText: though not quite as smoothly but it works fine. Beating down gangsters in Bruce Lee style martial arts fighting never gets old thankfully and is lots of fun. It is however
helpfulPercent: naturally much more grounded than Batman
votesHelpful: so donâ€™t expect to go all flying fists everywhere during a fight. It actually works very well having the game's combat so focused on melee. It changes things up and provides greater difficulty than having all the games fights be settled with guns. Now that doesnâ€™t mean that there aren't gun fights in this game because there sure are
votesTotal: lots of them and they have a John Woo film/Max Payne bullet time feature which is tons of fun. Particularly in the games third act. The guns fights really arenâ€™t very hard
votesFunny: about as difficult as a GTA game and play identically to GTA IV and V. Driving naturally is also something that you will do A LOT. It's just the part of the nature of sandbox games as GTA and Saints Row players will know and expect. The game has plenty of cars and motorcycles and other types of vehicles to get around in. Another welcome addition that sleeping dogs brings to the table is an easy
commentsCount: functional and basic parkour system. The games parkour is mostly just for making moving around the city easy
column16: fast and fun. You wonâ€™t be climbing buildings "Assassins Creed" style but it works well and makes movement lots of fun. Car combat is prevalent as well. The game allows you to shoot while driving with 360 degree aiming in a well-designed easy to use system. It makes crazy hi-octane car battles some of the highlights of Sleeping Dogs.\n\nThe game's story mission and side mission structure works identically to GTA. Thereâ€™s the main story missions marked with green icons on your map. Side missions are marked with variously coloured icons for different things such as: police missions
column17: favours for citizens of Hong Kong etc. Story missions feature a clever mechanic where you are graded on your performance as a Triad gangster and a cop based on your actions during a mission. Killing your enemies in effective and brutal ways will get you more points with your Triad score while minimizing damage to the public will get you points for your cop score. It really makes missions more interesting and gives good incentive to be precise and careful during missions. There are quite a lot of side missions to do as well but unfortunately this is where one of the games main flaws resides. Many of the less significant side missions are recycled and repetitive which can be boring and even some what frustrating. It terms of the main story itâ€™s also on the shorter side at thirty missions. It is an exciting
column18: intense and well done story however so it's easy to forgive its shorter length. The best side missions are for sure the police cases. These have you looking into serious crimes for the police while working outside the system. You investigate kidnapping of illegal immigrants
column19: serial killers
column20: organ harvesters
column21: the black market and hard core drug dealing. These all tell small stories on the side that are satisfying to play and solve. Street racing with various "classes" of vehicles ranging from class A-C is common and lots of fun
column22: especially with the class A vehicles. It helps that the driving is pretty well done in the game.\n\nNow aside from the main story and side missions there are other things you can do with your time as well. Karaoke is very popular in Hong Kong and when you go to clubs there are rooms where you can take part in a guitar hero style mini game of karaoke played with your keyboard or your controller. There aren't many songs to play but they are fun. You can also go hunting the collectables
column23: which thankfully are all helpful and actually do something. There are three kinds of collectables in the game: health shrines
column24: jade statues and lockboxes. There are fifty health shrines in total and like the name suggests finding them will increase your max health. There are like one hundred lockboxes that are full of money and unlock more clothing options. The best collectables though are for sure the twelve jade statues
column25: finding them allow you to unlock new moves to use in melee combat. These moves are taught to you by Wei's wise childhood sensei; every time you bring him one he has a heart to heart with Wei about his life choices and his past. They also discuss his life as a Triad but he cannot reveal his true nature as an undercover cop and itâ€™s surprisingly insightful.\n\nThe characters are very important of course
column26: Sleeping Dogs has a big cast of characters who are all well written and very well acted. Besides Wei there's his best friend and Triad member Jackie
column28: Police Superintendent Pendrew and many others. One thing that Sleeping Dogs brings back from GTA San Andreas is Wei having relationships with various women over the course of the story. However this is a big screw up in how Sleeping Dogs executes these relationships. Basically it works like this. You meet a woman and help her out
column29: and then she gives Wei her number. You go on one date with her and then at the end of the date you have sex which you see or hear none of (this sex comes way too easy by the way) and then you unlock some bonus after. The bonuses are actually really helpful so even though these relationships are so poorly done they are still totally worth doing. Another issue with the game is the celebrity voices. No the celebrities donâ€™t do bad jobs in their roles
column30: in fact they do well. However they are super underutilized
column31: Tom Wilkinson plays the police superintendent and even though it sounds super important he isnâ€™t in the game nearly as much as you would expect. Lucy Lui and Emma Stone are barley even in the game at all. A total waste of money and talent.\n\nAll in all Sleeping Dogs is a fun sandbox game. It has some notable flaws that hold it back from being in the same league as its competition and inspiration. It brings some welcome things to the sandbox game table with its parkour and emphasis on melee combat as well its clever cop/criminal dynamic with the protagonist. I can easily recommend this game when itâ€™s on sale.  8/10"

reviewText:
A review for Sleeping Dogs : Definitive Edition

In this review, most of the review will review the gameplay of the game, as I seen that the meat of the game should also be in its gameplay. While some game will require great interfaces, games that are focused on open-world fighting/shooting should be focused on its gameplay.

The first thing about this game, is that it has excellent gameplay, and quite varied with the well-established free-roaming games such as Grand Theft Auto series, Saints Row series, or Just Cause series. While four of them are great, the thing that makes Sleeping Dogs great is it have small amount of guns. It means that guns are hard to come by, most enemies don't have guns, and for the most part of the game you won't be using a gun.

You won't be using your gun, but you are using your fist and your martial skill, this is what makes the game interesting. As with other fighting games, you can chain combo, do heavy strikes, block and counter, and other typical fighting moves. As you collect collectibles in the game, you will gain more advanced martial arts strikes, thus making you are more potent combatant. For most of the game you will face off with your enemy with Triad enemies with your fist, so fighting in the game have more color than its FPS aspect. In the fighting, you and your enemies will use believable melee weapons such as knife, tire iron, batons, meat cleaver, and not using melee weapons that are scarcely available in modern settings such as spears, katanas, or swords. This makes the fighting more realistic.

The great aspect in the fighting is the environmental kills. These type of kills are brutal, that's for sure. reviewText:
Wow, I can't thank the developers of this game enough for an amazing job they have done to create a game that looks amazing and can be played flawlessly. The game has such fluid motion even in full throttle action racing through the streets and the gameplay from start to finish is very personal and inviting. From a PC Enthusiast I recommend this game over Watch Dogs and all the GTA's. I put this in the same category of joy to play a PC game as playing Tomb Raider, Kingdoms of Amular, Skyrim, Witcher 2, Batman Arkham City, Darksiders and Prince of Persia Forgotten Sands of Time. I'm not saying it is better or worse than these games but I thoroughly enjoyed these games and it's so hard to find a new game with these next generation high definition graphics that can play well, well this one plays amazingly. Thank you for updating this game and  getting it to play so well. I must admit to all gamers out there this game uses 95% on GPU1 and 97% on GPU2 of my GTX 690 and averages 55-60FPS at 1080P, reduces to 45FPS sometimes but I don't notice unless I watch the FPS counter. so it isn't going to play 60FPS for your everyday card but I do have the game on the most extreme settings.

reviewText: A beautiful remake of Sleeping Dogs, Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition brings many improvements, such as an increased population to the city (Hong Kong isn't a ghost town, after all), far better reflections, an everpresent and atmospheric fog, and much better textures. This of course causes much greater load on your machine, so be sure you've got enough juice. On my 7970s, it can get quite framey when deep in the city with large crowds. Otherwise, it runs at a buttery-smooth 60FPS.\nWhile some may dismiss this as a quick cash-grab, if you haven't had a chance to play Sleeping Dogs, now's your chance, and if you have, you'll enjoy the graphical improvements.\n

reviewText:
So is the definitive edition of Sleeping Dogs worth it if you have already played Sleeping Dogs on pc. Well from the get go you will notice the little details like Facial features.car textures,colors & the streets of hong kong are more populated with people I have never seen before & I have seen a lot in the original Sleeping Dogs in my 59 hours of playing it .

The lighting has also been imporved as well to give it that more realistic feel. There is also a legendary clothing shop which makes all the dlc clothing available for purchase & not just in your wardrobe which makes the process of going out collecting the red envlopes & opening lockboxes more enjoyable when you actually have to spend the time to work towards buying all your outfits instead of having a large sum of money towards the end game.

There are also some new cop missions as well from taking out gangs members to stopping a street race by taking out All the street racers before the race finishes.

Add that in with the bonus of getting all the dlc & you have yourself one of the best looking games on pc for a reasonable price.

For those that haven't played Sleeping Dogs yet what are you waiting for go & experience Wei Shen's Amazing story now.

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition is an Open World, with Third-Person Shooter and Martial Arts combat themes. There are many side tasks and side missions for you to run; races, fight clubs, gambling, police missions, and much more.

-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: You play as Wei Shen, an undercover cop attempting to infiltrate a Hong Kong criminal organization known as the Sun On Yee". Will Wei Shen keep his loyalties to the cops? will he become unstable from the stress? Will he be swayed to only work for the Sun On Yee and forsake his allegiances? You'll need to play to find out. (I'll tell you this much: I had no idea which direction we were going in this game.)

reviewText:
I give Sleeping Dogs: 8/10
SPOILER FREE! Sleeping Dogs is a really immersive game, not in terms of graphics but in terms of gameplay. We follow our main protagonist who is a cop, back in his hometown of Hong Kong where he grew up. Only this time, he's going undercover to stop big crime organisations such as the Sun On Yee (Sun Yee On in real life, yes they were real gangs). The game itself had some of the most fun gameplay features I've ever seen. The gameplay felt like I was really a part of Hong Kong.

Pros
The best feature about this game is the combat. The combat gameplay in this game is really mind-blowing because of how balanced it is. At times, it doesn't feel too easy but it isn't too hard either. I really liked how you can unlock new moves, and how the game focused more on brawling than gun gameplay.
The graphics in this game are really good, especially on the interior houses that you own. The character models could be improved a bit, so can the whole depth of field and atmosphere, but the world detail was really outstanding and I really liked it.
The character development in this game was really done well. You built relationships with the people around you, both cop and gang sides.
The sound is the game is really good too. It builds you into the environment like as if you are really there.
Performance wasn't an issue, the game ran really smooth on high.
Cons
the worst thing about sleeping dogs in my opinion was the driving. The driving felt really stiff and at times, racing was a lot harder because of this. Yes there was handbrakes and braking, but the driving just didn't really make me like how it was controlled.
Lack of vehicle catergories. There was hardly any wide ranges of cars/bikes, and besides that, there is only on land and on sea vehicles. That showed the game with less variety.
The map is really short and inconvinient. Sometimes, the map felt really short and didn't make Hong Kong seem big at all. It would have been better if the map was a lot bigger.
I hope you have enjoyed my review of Sleeping Dogs. I recommend this game to anyone who wants to play a Fast and Furious like game, (or even a Kung Fu movie).

Story        Graphics        Performance        Soundtrack        Enjoyment        Overall                8        7        8        7        8        7.6

reviewText:
I've played the original Sleeping Dogs and it was a pretty great game. This version is no different, however, it has improvements that make me recommend it over the original. The performance is solid, the controls are more natural for PC players, and really looks better in general. There's things like HDAO that make cutscenes look great, improved models, city density, better lighting and reflections, and of course, everyone's favorite, lens flare. I'd say it's a great game to get into if you haven't played it before. If you have, it's definately worth playing through again with all the pretty graphics and blinky lights. All the DLC is included as well so there is a lot available from the get-go. Visit the trading forum to get this game really cheap!

I don't support this type of behavior from developers, but I liked the original and got it for free with my graphics card. I've always wanted to play the DLC missions as well, so this was an instant buy for me. Adding the solid 60fps that I didn't get from the original, I'd have to recommend it.

Also, having FRAPS open disables the overlay.

I'd give this a 9/10.
voteText: 24 of 34 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A great open world game with a lot to do, excellent cast and plot, fun fluid martial arts combat and some good action-movie styled gunplay/shootouts. The sidemissions in the game are generally fun, although the drug busts can get repetitive. Decent character customization, but some bad animation besides in the cutscenes (which were done with motion capture I imagine) and the martial arts combat, which felt very fluid.

Gunplay was alright, it wasn't the highlight of the game but it was still very fun, and the slow-motion while vaulting and shooting was very satisfying. The graphics are good, the model detail was good for the most part, although the detail on the civilians was pretty bad for the most part, as to be expected with an open world game.

Overall, this game is a fun open-world interpretation of Hong-Kong. In my opinion it's worth more than the 30$ it's selling at right now.
If I was to rate it, I'd give it an 8/10. Favorite Square-Enix game in my opinion.

reviewText:
Well... after finishing the story mode of the game in 2 days I can honestly say, this was an amazing journey.

Introduction to the game
You start the game as Wei Shen, a former police officer in San Francisco who's been transfered to a fictional hong kong which is split into four districts. Wei Shen has been assigned to destroy a Triad organization by the name of Sun On Yee.
From there on out the game splits you into two characters - Wei Shen, police officer and Wei Shen, a member of the triad organization.

Gameplay
â†’ The Combat
The combat system in this game is quite simple and easy to use, you fight with the click of your left mouse button and dodge incomming hits by pressing E at the right time. I really relish the fighting moments in the game where the character is faced off against 8 or more enemies at the same time, prooves quite a challenge at first but gets easier the more you do it. Another big thing in a lot of games are guns, not in this game though. You don't get a gun in your hand in the first 2 hours atleast into the game, you actually feel how powerful guns are in the game once you get them. You'll be spending most of the game fighting enemies with your fists or some other melee weapon rather then a pistol or an automatic.

â†’ The Vehicles
Similarly to other games you can steal vehicles from a parking lot or the road by brutally janking the driver out, taking his place. Of course you don't have to steal vehicles, there is another to get a vehicle.
There's a large variety of vehicles in the game for you to choose from. Once you obtain these vehicles in your garage you can choose 3-5 colors of your car and where you wish to recieve it from, there are multiple spots on the map from which you may take an infinite amount of these vehicles from. Some vehicles handle very nicely, others not so much. Occasionally you will run into a police situation from which you must escape and in this game it is quite easy, you just drive out of their detection zone and any ammount of police attention you had is just suddenly gone. Unfortunately there's no way of getting any air vehicles - Helicopters, planes etc. The sea vehicles are a bit of frustrating to control as they turn very slowly.

â†’The Minigames
Sometimes you just want to take a break from the story mode but what do you do then? Do you go shoot people? Do you go explode cars? The answer is no. You go and sing karaoke â†“
Me trying Karaoke
If karaoke isn't your thing you can also enjoy an exciting adrenaline rushing race in the streets of hong kong, or perhaps you feel like busting some crimes, you can!

â†’ The collectibles
Throughout the map are placed many collectable items like statues, which you can give your old sensei in return for a new fighting technique. Then there are healing statue things which collecting will give you permanently more health, money can also be found in briefcases with sometimes a piece of clothing.

â†’The Extras
You can also purchase with ingame money clothing for Wei Shen which he will wear in any cutscene in the game, I think that's a very neat feature to the game aswell.

The Story
This game's story was really quite the journey, you can really feel the emotions of the characters in the game. Excitement, anger, grief, relief - all emotions that I've felt while playing this amazing masterpiece of a game, and if you really listen to the dialogue you will feel too. This is one of those games where once you start playing, you can't stop untill it's done.

Final Vertdict
This game has been a wonderful expirience for me and I suggest everyone to play it and enjoy it too. If you don't think you can run the definitve edition you should atleast buy the orginal. I'd rate this game a 10/10 for the pure depth of the game and story of it.

reviewText:
This open world, third person action feels a lot like Saints Row with a more serious note. There's blood and scenarios are merciless.

The game is mainly fought with fists, but guns are available on select missions. Some situations are crazy, specially the bike races - NPCs will ram the flag girl at the start. The rest of the way, they will go crazy on you.

Car physics are not easy to control. Ramming (button) can also be used while going sideways, which could be exploited when racing or driving fast in general. If you think races are difficult, just race later after you have the prototype car - then races can get funny.

Movement is also awkward (I am using a mouse and keyboard setup). Camera angles in any mode (car / bike / foot) is hard to control, and you can't look too far up (which I find weird and sometimes irritating). On foot, turning is not as precise or quick as in other games (or even compared to real life). This can be frustrating in fighting... until you realize that you can use a car or bike to win them. The game is probably programmed more towards using a gamepad.

Soundtrack is good. I only started to get tired of them after more than 30 hours of playing.

Graphics are good, but sometimes can't keep up when driving fast. It only required 50% at 750MHz from my GTX 770, so I think many gamers can play this game.

Sound effects are amazing. It has perfect use of audio positioning and environmental sounds are there. Though, at times, motor boat and water splashing sounds were skipping (not produced) for a few seconds in intervals.

The story is alright, and the story telling is fine. Events can sometimes get weird. You can't grab who you're chasing (even when you're already touching them) until you've reached the end where you'll fight a group or they simply give up; but at the same time, as part of the game rule, you can't be too far away from them (again, in a chase scenario).

This game scored a 5/10 for me, but I'm labeling it as a Recommend for the story telling and overall good fun. The controls is the biggest let-down as I was forced to play with a hard to control character until I finish it. The game has a serious note, but remember that this is a game and better just take full advantage of what you can do to avoid character control, camera and other possible frustrations it could give you.

reviewText: Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition is a frenzied, artistic action game that, though it is marred by slight technical difficulties, still provides an enjoyable alternative to the standard action-sandbox.\n\nSleeping Dogs' greatest strength comes from its presentation. The developers implemented the game's open-world replica of Hong Kong painstakingly with striking visuals and smartly interconnected layouts, which help the player see this beautifully-realized city from all angles. The characters' presentations are also done in an effective manner. The effort put into the story of the main character especially pays off, as gamers can easily identify with the upbringing and struggles that drive development of protagonist Wei Shen as he searches to define himself between connections with the Hong Kong Police and the gang Sun On Yee. Wei is joined by a cast of secondary characters that would generally fall into the category of stereotypical"
date: but fortunately most have some extraordinary developments or twists that keep them from becoming stale or predictable.\n\nComparisons between Sleeping Dogs and the Grand Theft Auto series are commonplace. However
recommended: such claims made in an attempt to denigrate Sleeping Dogs is
hoursPlayed: at best

reviewText:
[Disclaimer]
Sigh* I had already finished this game twice but steam didnt record that time nor achievement because I didn't have internet at that time 24/7 so none of my time or achievement register. The ones you see are just me checking to make sure the game is still alright before doing my review.

Game Info Name: Sleeping Dogs
Developer: United Front Games
Genre: Beat Em Up, Kung Fu, Action, Stealth, Racing
Personal Verdict: Ever wanted to put a leg up someones face? Do so in HD.

What is Sleeping Dogs:Definitive Edition
Originally Sleeping Dogs without the Definitive Edition tack to it this version sees square enix adding and adjusting the entire DLC released in Sleeping Dog previous version into something well errr, better. Anyways to the game itself.

Sleeping Dog is a visceral game of Kung-Fu, betrayal, triads and friendship as we follow one Wei Shen as he does his job in the brilliantly rendered world of Hong Kong, Wei must choose between his allegiance to the triads or to his police officers as he delivers justice. One Kung-Fu at a time.

Story
Playing the story of Sleeping Dogs [SD] reminds me of the old action Kung-Fu movie where the story moves at breakneck speed and emotional rollercoaster happens all the time. Which is to say the story kick â™¥â™¥â™¥. It delivers them in spades and is not afraid to hold back from doing all sorts of nasties that the player will no doubt witness and feel.

Graphic
Usually I do not like to talk much about graphics because what the heck am I suppose to write?! Exception of course are made. Sleeping Dogs treats the world of Hong Kong is pretty bland with repetitive civilian, normal texture etc etc but it really comes alive during the night and rain! Especially night and rain together in tandem!

Skins exude a sheen, cars has powerful reflection upon them and everything is generally 10x better than it is during daytime. Not to say the standard graphics are bad but upping it up and witnessing the full glory of the engine in rain and night is a breathtaking experience.

Sound
United Front Games pulled no punches in making sure we get the most authenthic experience for our stay in Hong Kong. Random quips in Cantonese can be heard as you walk the streets, Character that do not speak english instead does full Cantonese dialogue. The crisp clear audio makes subtitle a secondary thing as oppose to be a mandatory on for most games and every effect down to the last mission complete evoke a strangely nostalgic chinese feel.

Gameplay
Ah Sleeping Dogs, I turn you on, kick a few citizen stuff them into the boot of their car then kill them right in front of the hospital with my KUNG-FU. What better way to start a monday.

In an otherwise typical fare of open world game Sleeping Dog does the competition shame by focusing on one aspect many game have neglected: The melee system. While initially the melee system seems easy with 1 hko object scattered all over the enviroment and enemies come in weak and puny form they soon ramp it up especially towards midgame where you will be punching, kicking and hurling foes off rail while covered in blood. Essentially press counter when enemy glow red, punch them up till they die and then when the meter is full use face mode to recover health and make your enemy fear you.

Along the way explore the world! Beat up people in side activities to uncover drug raids, beat people up again to obtain chests of money and clothing. Turn Wei into the most fashion savvy freak with the game large customization option. Engage in daring fights as you beat up people to get money and more face value!

Or perhaps you're a picky one eh? Want a bit of dialogue and action in your beat em up? Look no further. Turn into a cop hunt down people as you become the scourge of the underworld, help your eccentric group of buddies as they get into random hijinks that often ends with beating people up. Or you know, just help around the citizen of Hong Kong, they could use a help from a friendly people-beating gangster.

But alas the gunplay fall shorts, since most resources went into fighting people up the gun lacks recoil, feels plasticky and holds no weight. Cleverly the game wave them away from most mission by stating HONG KONG DON'T ALLOW GUNS!" it works for me it should works for you.

The car good to say however is awesome and a joy to ride
date: and since you can simply steal a car it doesnt matter if you're walking on foot
recommended:
simply steal a car and be on your way. Or you can use the car valet. Eh. Fun feature includes the ability to steal cars within a car without going out. Amazing when you think about it since you don't have to dismount but can happily continue your ride in a shiny new car as the wreck of your old ones burns behind you.

Completing mission earns you triad points by being brutal and police point for being civilised lawful cop. Leveling up gives you a choice of perk within the skill tree.

An oddly choice of collectible
hoursPlayed:
side missions and all that jazz ensures you won't be bored of the game anytime soon.

Conclusion
How I wish i could experience it all over again

reviewText:
10/10
Amazing Game

I have finished the original version multiple times already and am still amazingly impressed by it's realistic feel of Hong Kong and how it's archetecture reflects on various different area's.

Most would know Triads did exist around year 1950 and were incorporated into the game so realisticly and did things real triads did (Trafficing Drugs, fighting and prostitution) and being able to play through it as Wei Shen is like being in HK. Triad groups in the game were based on the real Son Yee On and 14K as they were real enemies.

I love the use of stereotypes in the game and found them especially funny because i do speak Cantonese as a first language and i am astonished at how accurately dialogue in the city is put into a game where you can freely explore the vibrant culture of HK.

It is a game you can keep on playing, and never get bored of.

reviewText:
For those waiting for GTA V or a similar open world type game, Sleeping Dogs fills the gap suitably. The structure of the game is no surprise for any GTA player, or if you have played the previous True Crime games, with the only major difference here is that the game's combat is based on a Batman-style melee approach, which is suitably fun once you get the hang of it and identify the various moves. It does get a bit repetative towards the end of the main mission set, but that's common with most open world games; there's also a good deal of completionist gathering one can go after. However, elements like the story itself are somewhat lackluster - you can get an idea where the story is heading early on, and there's not much redeeming or vile about any of the characters.

The Definition Edition includes two packs of DLC, both adding another 2-3 hr each of gameplay. The second one, Year of the Snake, feels like a good single movie in terms of plot (attempting to stop a cult bombing the city), while the first one has fun elements of movies like Big Trouble in Little China in it.

The only issue that I have against the game is a lack of technical updates from the publisher, which many have commented on the forums. In my case, I had started the game, and during that time had to update a completely separate hardware driver for a camera device, among other things. This caused the game to be inoperable. Only until I was at a point that I had replaced the camera with a different one, did the game then work fine. As one of the few troubleshooting tips they have given has been to disconnect all USB devices which have worked for some but not all, this might create a technical problem for you.

reviewText:
A suspense action-thriller, organized crime story, of a multidimensional Asian American undercover agent, whose loyalty is tested in extreme circumstances brought by a dark past he left behind.

Hugely underrated, Sleeping Dogs is the surprise cult hit of 2012, and delivered an honorable tribute to masterpiece films, such as Infernal Affairs, and its Hollywood remake, The Departed.

Sandbox gameplay set in a highly detailed cosmopolitan city, fully fleshed out with fresh style of slick eastern-esque aesthetics, well suited for the enigmatic Hong Kong Triad theme. Primary combat is raw hand-to-hand packed with myriad true-to-life martial techniques to employ; a feature that adds to its unique flavor when compared to GTA or Watch Dogs.

Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition (2014) is more than worth the asked price point.  Experience this gem today!

reviewText:
Sleepings Dogs: Definitive Edition,

Is the first game in its genre that's actually able to keep me interested. Game's like GTA and Saints Row, which do a good job on their own, don't come even close to what Sleeping Dogs offers me when it comes down to gameplay, handling, atmosphere, voice overs and hints of reality.
The city of (virtual) Honk Kong is beautifully dirty and down to earth. The people all look very realistic and not like some comic book character. The cars look the way they should look: normal.
There're many mini games throughout the main game and they all blend in perfectly and make sens in one way or another. It's nothing stupid, but fitting.
Another good thing is that random violence is not rewarded, but rather punished. Especially when doing a mission.

If you're looking for a game that's very similar to GTA or Saints Row, but want a somewhat more realistic setting, then get Sleeping Dogs. It provides action, drama, fun and visuals for content tourists; all on a very, very high level.

The two DLC's that come with the definitive edition provide each 2-3 hours of extra gameplay and I've got to be honest that the year of the Snake" DLC suprised me in a very positive way. That's because you're actually playing as a police officer. (Wearing the uniform and all) As which your main goal is to cover up some cultist scheme and to arrest people. (Opposite of killing)"

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs features Wei Shen, an undercover cop struggling to balance his Triad loyalty and police responsibilities on the streets of Hong Kong.

The game features a well-crafted martial arts combat system, blending combos, counters, light and heavy attacks, and grabs/throws to create freeform fights that emphasize flow and diversity over efficiency. Environmental attacks and upgradeable special moves round out the variety.

The real selling point is the map design - Hong Kong is lovingly rendered with beautiful levels of detail, from crowded market streets to curved highways overlooking endless rows of shipping docks. It's a delight to simply drive along the coastal highways and listen to the rippling shoreline or zip around the market districts. It's downright breathtaking, and stands head and shoulders above GTA's cities in terms of sheer visual interest.

The story is solid, albeit a bit standard. Gunplay, driving, and some side activities like gambling or drug busts provide a solid variety of activities for the entire map. Music, sound and voice acting are top-notch.

This is a a polished and cinematic take on the GTA sandbox formula, I thoroughly recommend it.

reviewText:
I probably should have left this review on the original Sleeping Dogs game, but here we go anyways. Probably contains spoilers so consider yourself warned.

\ Story:
The story is an amazingly tangled mess of triad fighting and personal choices. It is going to break you down inside and i was left a crying mess throughout the game. It should be said that i am very easily attached to, and affected by things. The wedding, where the oh so sad love song always plays before â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ is going down, Uncle Po, and not to forget the most horrible death of them all (to me at least), Jackie.. The last had me bawling my eyes out because the story and character had sucked me in (and i kinda had a minor crush on Edison Chen). Anyhow, the story is solid, A+.

\ Gameplay and graphics:
The improved graphics are stunning, and almost killed my computer because i was overly confident while choosing the ultra high settings. It was definitely worth the upgrade and it was even more immersive this time around than the first. I sat for eight hours the first day and ten hours the second to finish the game and i've never gotten so sucked into anything before. The vibrant colors and the city itself feels even more realistic now. I love the random encounters with people selling art and birds and whatnot too. And the food looks so amazingly good i just keep drooling every time i look at it.

The only thing that annoyed me was towards the end of the game when the car valet kept saying he was busy and couldnt deliver to you, but apart from that i have nothing negative to say.

Easily one of my favorite games and one of the best i've played so far.

reviewText:
So in this game you play as an immoral wank*r (Triad Member) who is actually a professional wank*r (Police Officer) in a city once ruled by imperial wank*rs (Hong Kong). Yup... and you can be sure that my psycho-side was in full force when I played this. I just couldn't help myself. XD

It's basically a sandbox crime game, but with the added twist of you sometimes doing sandbox stuff where you punch crime instead. Or taze it. Or shoot it. Or arrest it. Or... yeah not continuing this. Anyway, there's lots of side missions, collectibles, places to explore, minigames, and citizens to beat the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ out of when they make rude remarks about your clothes, hit you with their car, or just simply exist. Honestly, I didn't need reasons to act like a total sociopath (even moreso than I do in the Saints Row games, which is really saying something), so I had a tendency to act like one...

...except during alot of missions when it actually has negative effects. Basically you have three leveling systems: Police (which you get xp for by obeying the law and punching criminals on police missions), Triad (for punching people or slamming their head into... woah that was uncalled for), and Face (for helping people, which I find funny since pride pretty much never involves being a benefactor). It's pretty obvious which of these three leveling systems I didn't get much XP for. The minigames were kinda silly, particularly that karaoke stuff and the whole collecting girl phone numbers thing (which I never called because I never got that bored). At least the combat is pretty good.

There is a story, and it's actually pretty good. At times predictable, and I often felt as if my main character was being way too antagonistic towards his police handler. But it's good. Also its crazy-violent, because gangsters who talk about codes and honor are the last people to actually respect such things. And while I was not torn at all about whose side I was on (because Triad people are scum), I did cheer a few times when they did stuff I wanted them to do, such as when the character I hated the most (because he pulled a Walder Frey, which made me think about the RW" and all that comes with that) ended up being killed by a crazed lady feeding him one of his henchmen and chopping him with a meat cleaver. And while that was certainly satisfying
date: it wasn't one of the many ideas I had between the "Hong Kong RW" and that scene about what way I would have ended that guy (or Walder Frey). I had an alarming tendency to ponder what outrageous act of violence I wanted to see end the lives of certain characters
recommended: most of which were more brutal than what actually happened. I really must be a psycho. >_<\n\nAnyway... sandbox crime

reviewText: I put around 100 hours into the original Sleeping Dogs several years back on my old PC; on my new, much more powerful machine, I was thrilled to play the definitive edition. It's not merely a re-release - it's a reworking of the graphics and a slight improvement on the already fluid and fun combat system, and it contains additions to the campaign (extended narrative, extra cop side missions) that are worthy of the repurchase cost for fans who already have the original (specifically those who liked it and want to play it again). Because I had already finished the campaign as well as played through the DLC episodes, I was hesitant to buy the same game twice, but when it went on sale for $7.50, I struck and was very happy I did. This is not only an extended and much more immersive experience; it works better on newer software and hardware architecture. It manages to pack Hong Kong more densely with NPCs and greatly improve environmental textures and weather while demanding much less of my GPU than the original release. They both hit some of the same framerates, but with settings cranked, my video card chugs along very loudly to the original release while it's capable of rendering more with less power in the definitive edition. Truly an optimal redesign for the PC.\n\nFor the many who've already played Sleeping Dogs and loved it, I 100% recommend picking up the definitive edition IF you want to play through the campaign again or if you haven't played the DLC episodes (and I'd wait for a sale). You may find the experience enjoyable as I did or you may feel like you're wading through the same water (albeit much more detailed and highly rendered water). If you've never played the game, this is the edition to get - it's a very fun open world game in the vein of Grand Theft Auto with tons of collectibles, a martial arts beat 'em up combat system, great driving mechanics, fun missions and side-objectives, and, most importantly of all, a good story fronted by a compelling protagonist who leads a double life as both an undercover cop & triad member and a Chinese-American immigrant & Chinese national. As another Asian-American who's faced confusion stemming from a bi-cultural background, I find Wei Shen to be a well written, sympathetic and multi-faceted hero/anti-hero. In addition, the ties the campaign and DLC episodes share with HK Crime and Kung Fu films (references, atmosphere, setting, style) alone are enough to draw me in to its highly detailed vision of modern Hong Kong and keep me playing in it time and time again.

reviewText:
Cool game, lovely voice work and great graphics. The environments are nice and the combat is fun. However there is one thing that I cannot shake when I play this and it is very irritating. It feels like a poor man's GTA. Driving vehicles is no fun either, mostly because when using a mouse and keyboard, the camera is awkward. Reversing on a bike will spin the camera, but if you manually move the mouse to get a better look as you set off forward, it will still rotate the camera and as such go beyond the forward view - as if it has to complete the entire motion. Why they couldn't of made it so moving the camera view yourself resets the camera spin, I just don't know.

There are are a few other minor annoyances. Sometimes AI will walk into things, which isn't that bad really and many games are guilty of that (ahem Payday 2), but one of my biggest gripes when playing on foot is that there is no toggle for walk and run. Instead, if you want to walk you must rely on holding the free aim button (which is right click by default). However using free aim to walk is evidently not the proper way of doing it because whenever you get near an interactable object that you wish to talk past, your guy will just... sort of strafe past it while trying to get it in focus. Bit daft really that they couldn't simply add a walk toggle button.

Another annoyance? The weird buttons. The game plays brilliantly with mouse and keyboard, but I have no idea why some menus rely solely on pressing Left-CTRL and Right-CTRL and Backspace and Enter. Why couldn't a cursor be implemented? Seems a bit lazy if you ask me.

Overall, of what I've played (among some other very minor bugs which I've decided not to mention here), the game is excellent and well worth the money if you haven't already got the base game. For those who have the original Sleeping Dogs, I wouldn't necessarily say the increase in graphical fidelity and draw distance was worth it... although that is ultimately your decision.

reviewText: One of the best games I have ever played! Gorgeous 3rd person shooter! Includes a ton on DLC's, properly integrated into the main story - unlike the Standard Edition of Sleeping Dogs, which had some dlc's that for e.g. would give you an unfair advantage, right from the beginning of the game. Also, some DLC's are unlocked as you progress through the main story and there are two more DLCs, that can be accessed from the Main Menu, which are separated from the main game. This game is much more optimized (a very good port) than GTA IV & GTA EFLC (see the notes below). I was able to play maxed out this game with a MSI GeForce GTX 970 GAMING 4G (I OC'd it a little though :D). The only thing I haven't cranked on maximum was the AA (which I left it on High, NOT Extreme, 'cause it affected the FPS too damn much). Otherwise, it was very well optimized and it was a pleasure driving around this fictional Hong Kong, killing pokg@is :)) and enjoying the beautiful storyline :)

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs was originally released on August 13, 2012 for Xbox 360, PS3, and PC. It was recently released on Xbox One and PS4 as well. It was developed by United Front Games and published by Square Enix. It received a 9 out of 10 on Steam, 4 out of 5 on Metacritic and an 8.5 out of 10 on IGN.

While most people consider Sleeping Dogs a GTA knock off set in Hong Kong, I would argue that perception is false. While the initial concept is the same, an open world crime game, the basic mechanics of Sleeping Dogs sets it apart. These mechanics include cop/triad alliances, a focus on melee combat, and a Max Payne esque bullet time when sliding over objects during gun play.

Because of the great implementation of the aforementioned mechanics, the smaller size of the open world compared to similar releases such as GTA and Watch_Dogs, still provides a fantastic experience.

The story in follows an ex San Francisco cop that has been thrown back into the world of the Triads in modern day Hong Kong. While the story may seem cliche at first, if you give it some time you will find a rewarding plot line to follow.

The Definitive Edition includes six downloadable content packages for your consumption, and with the current holiday sale on Steam, is well worth the additional cost.
voteText: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Sleeping Dogs takes you on a blood-spattered journey through the violent Hong Kong underworld as undercover cop Wei Shen, a man torn between two worlds and not wholly of either one. The game is a sandbox crime sim and is closer to Grand Theft Auto then to Saints Row in terms of gameplay, but is generally more enjoyable to play then the former. It does however lack any kind of multiplayer, which I am sure would be very offputting for some. While it places a much lower emphasis on shooting then most games in the genre, it flavors its gunfights with bullet time- but most of the time, Wei engages his foes with a brutal combination of strikes, counters and throws, coupled with some very painful-looking environmental finishers (table saws, spikes, furnaces, fan blades- the list goes on) You unlock additional melee techniques along the way and while the fights may eventually get stale and lack the tactical depth of say, the Batman: Arkham games, they remain a cut above the drunken flailing that passes for melee in GTA V. Unlike the purely aesthetic clothing options in GTA V, clothing in Sleeping Dogs can provide bonuses when worn as a set.  Driving is manageable, though most the cars do not handle very well and you will find yourself grinding a lot of hard surfaces at speed. However, you have the ability to jolt your car left, right or forwards to ram other cars, which is both useful and entertaining. Bullet time also kicks in when aiming a gun from a car, making engaging pursuers infinitely easier. As per standard for the genre, there are a multitude of collectables scattered about the map. While the lockboxes reward only some money and occasionally clothes and the security camera hacks offer no reward at all, the shrines confer a maximum health upgrade for every five shrines found and are absolutely vital, as finding them all doubles Wei's starting health. Luckily, you unlock the ability to see the shrines on your map early on, and like GTA V, the entire city is available to explore at the start, barring only a few story mission-only areas.  This definitive" edition of the game includes almost all of the DLCs- fair enough

reviewText: While I like the graphical improvements and other tweaks, I must say I'm somewhat disappointed with the lack of bug fixes.  There's a few times where you can fail a mission randomly due to bad AI (ie: if you have an ally driving for you and they flip the car) or just some inexplicable auto-fails.  Nonetheless, the concept of the game is very appealing and is mostly well done.  It doesn't have the same polish as GTA in some ways but the martial arts combat system and parkour is way more advanced than what GTA has.  One terrible thing in this game is that you can't seem to hail a cab without car jacking half the time.  Nobody thought of using  another button for the car jacking?  Bugs and minor headaches aside, it's definitely a buy if you haven't played the original version and love games like GTA and Saints Row.

Also the pricetag is great, it's well worth Â£19.99

It has amazing parkour mechanics, With smooth yet realistic mechanics, The slow-motion is possibly the best around and dont get me started on the figthing mechanics... Maghad. The fighting mechanics are possibly the best I have seen in years. GTA's fighting mechanics are... Okay, But compared to Sleeping Dogs', GTA is on its hands and feet. Its a mass of fun to play, WIth vastly updated mechanics and content, And when you buy the game, You get all 24 DLC's included with it. The graphics have been updated, But not that much tbh. 9/10

reviewText: Sleepy Dogs is one of my all time favorite open world games. I played this game for the first time last year and promised myself that I would eventually buy all of the DLC and replay the game eventually.  When the Definitive edition came out, I knew I had to get it immediately.  The DE sprinkles the newly unlocked DLC throughout the story so you are not immediately over powered at the start with crazy guns/cars/money.  That was a very good thing and added much to the overall gameplay.  The graphic upgrade was a nice touch as well.  In all, if you are thinking about buying Sleeping Dogs the DE is definitely the one to get.\n\n2015 Edit: After playing GTA 5, I can safely say that I enjoyed my time with this game more than Grand Theft Auto. I wish that Sleepy Dogs could have a touch more of the amazing world building that GTA has. But that's it. I S ranked this game and would STILL be willing to take another spin in the world of Sleepy Dogs.
