reviewText:
One day this game went on to Xbox Live for a free game with gold so I decided to get it. It was the original version and this one hadn't come out yet. I loved the game so much, and it was my favorite game. Sadly, my Xbox broke for unknown reasons and I was unable to play the game for a while. Then one day i see that this new and improved version of Sleeping Dogs has been released, and by then I had purchased a gaming PC so I was very exited when I found out I would be able to play Sleeping Dogs once again.
I bought this, downloaded it, and played it. I spent 15 hours playing it on my first day of owning it.

Now, the Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition goes through various improvements from the previous version. I will now go step by step describing them.

Graphical Stuff: 9/10
The trailer boasts about graphical and texture improvements, and they weren't lying. There aren't much improvements to the graphics as there are to the textures. Lighting is very clearly improved and clothing and hair are no longer static. There is a few minor glitches to this kind of things but nothing too noticeable.

Audio: 5/10
I personally cant see much difference.

Gameplay: 8/10
Sleeping Dogs: DE has a few changes to the gameplay. For example, the city of Hong Kong feels much more immersive, there is more pedestrians and traffic making Hong Kong feel more like Hong Kong. The driving mechanics feel much smoother and better. But now for cons. some of the walking controls feel very wonky and sometimes it is more difficult to actually do the parkour in the game. The game is also no longer able to generate everything in your general area, so sometimes you'll take a few step and all of a sudden the game will span a group of civilians right next to Wei. and sometimes people spawn in the sky and fall to Earth. but overall, really good gameplay.

SPOILERS FROM HERE ON!

I love this game so much, the story is amazing and there is so much attachment to characters. I felt bad for Mrs. Chu when Winston died at his wedding, and cried when Wei found Jackie Ma's dead body. When you find that Pendrew was a bad guy I was shocked. So much happens within this game and I hope to never stop playing it

That's why my final rating for this game is 9/10.

reviewText:
A great open-world action game. I was drawn in immediately by the aesthetic, which is done very well, and kept playing because of the simple, yet very satisfying, brutal combat system. With strings of combos, you can break enemies' legs, arms, faces, and smash them into fans and refridgeraters.

The story is good - it feels a little more fresh to be part of the police, working undercover. It doesn't go quite as deep as I had hoped it would, but the game does openly explore some moral boundaries related to killing which adds depth.

While the driving is a bit wonky, and at times frustrating, the burnout-style ramming" is really fun and arcadey.

Overall
date: this is a great action game
recommended: and one I would even recommend over grand theft auto."

I own both, but recommend that first time buyers buy the original + all DLC if you want to *play* in the world, if you just want to grab the game and beat it, don't care about anything else...get this, on sale.

reviewText: If you have played the original Sleeping Dogs released back In 2012 then you're probaly wondering why you should get the game again,well simply put the game Is amazing and Is more detailed and better looking then ever.The lighting In this game Is absolutely amazing and Is noticeable especially at night and when It Is raining,plus with the addition of Volumetric Fog you really feel like you're In Hong Kong.Also another Inprovement over the original release Is the Increase of NPC's roaming the street's of Hong Kong,more pedestrian's walking and the Increase of traffic throughout the city really bring's the game to life and give's you the feeling of the reality of everyday Hong Kong,the Night Market was one of my favourite place's In the game due to the fact that It Is absolutely crowded with NPC'S and you can constantly hear people yelling out to either yourself or other NPC'S trying to sell food or clothing,It make's you feel like you're In the everyday market's that are packed In Hong Kong.From the story's point of view I think It Is very well done and It Is really Interesting,I wasn't bored at any point during the game and the action got better and better as the story progressed,I would buy this game again just for the sake of the story alone because It Is very good.From the technical point of the game It Is extremely well optimized with a constant 60FPS! at 1080P however the extreme Anti Aliasing setting which use's SSAA Is extremely demanding and i would turn the setting down to high as I noticed no major difference in picture quality but did get better performance,also there was no game breaking bug's or freeze's.I would recommended this game to everybody,the story Is absolutely solid!,there Is plenty and I mean plenty of side mission's,collectibles and DLC's to be enthralled In.and also lot's of action packed fun exploring Hong Kong.\nSo would I recommend people who bought the original Sleeping Dogs back In 2012 to buy the game again,absolutely!\nIf you never played Sleepings Dogs before,well then you must buy this game,It Is a one of a kind game and to both fan's and newcomer's of the game,It truly Is the Definitive Edition!

reviewText:
As Wei Shen you'll be infiltrating the Sun On Yee Triad in an effort to bring it down not only to do your duty as a police officer but also to avenge your sister, who died of an overdose after being introduged to drugs by a triad member.
Sleeping Dogs is a truly good game providing an interesting storyline, realistic open world, a good amount of quests and side activities and a fun melee combat system: the Definitive Edition features several improvements such as better graphics, more side missions and previously released DLC.

PROS:

-great plot, the story is truly engaging and mantains a good momentum from beginning to end

-a good cast of characters that, while not extremely deep, manage to be as realistic as they are interesting

-Hong Kong is a very interesting setting and one the devs managed to recreate very well both in looks and ambience: it truly feels alive

-good graphics overall, while not extremely detailed they feature many small details both on characters and in the game world

-excellent soundtrack, the ingame radios have a good amount of different genres available and, while not as famous as GTA, they're all very good

-huge amount of things to do between main missions, side quests, favours, lockboxes, cop jobs and even more collectibles

-meleee combat is extremely fun and gets better as you unlock new moves, gunplay happens a bit less often (especially at the beginning) but works well and has a decent cover system

-the extra content from the DLCs adds even more hours to a long base game

CONS:

-if you already played the base game, the graphical improvements are generally minor

-some extra activities (races, cop jobs) can get repetitve in the long run

-camera can sometimes turn at awkard angles during melee fights or while entering a vehicle

-a few hiccups with the AI, especially pedestrian or civilian drivers

-lacks Cloud saving

-a few bugs here and there (a cutscene zooming out due to my character getting slightly stuck on a rock, some NPCs getting stuck on scenery,a couple flashing textures): very minor things though

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=525573571

Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition was a joy to play, and I say so as someone who had played the original game back then and decided to replay it in its improved form: the story is great, Wei Shen is a good lead character and the plethora of missions, activities and stuff to buy/ collect ensures you never have time to get bored. If you somehow missed the game back in 2012 then you owe to yourself to buy this one.Igf you already own the base game, well, I'd be worthwhile to get this one if you havn't experienced the story DLCs since they'll add about 2 hours each.

I got this on sale for around 8$ and got 30ish hours out of it, that's a great bang for your buck: if you also consider the game's quality, they make Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition a game I fully recommend, previous consideration notwithstanding.

reviewText:
Jet Li meets The DepartedSleeping Dogs satisfies the need for a fast paced, action packed crime thriller with a gripping story line. Competing with the ever popular Grand Theft Auto franchise, Square Enix has delivered a masterpiece of dramatic, story-telling adventure. And the story is where Sleeping Dogs surpasses the competition.
SD strikes a neat balance between action and cutscenes -- which are beautifully directed. I never found myself waiting for the scene to end, perhaps due to their brevity, but definitely because they're fun to watch! The plot is gripping, the characters are authentic, and their journeys are moving.
There are a couple of parts where the plot progression seems rushed, but character development still feels genuine. About half-way through the game, I started to feel like Jackie was my best friend too! And did I mention how great the animation in the cutscenes looks?
At least as important as the story telling is the gameplay. Like other games in it's genre, it has a tendency to throw control mechanics at you that are overly simple, yet obnoxiously difficult to execute. Combat and driving controls come with a steep learning curve, but are manageable... but only just. Despite the difficulty, fist fighting a bunch of thugs, or shooting it out while slow mo flying over obstacles is a blast! This all does get easier as you level up with the build ssytem learning new kung fu techniques and street criminal tactics, Add in parkour and some fun mini games to break up the monotony and it's a really fun experience. This game isn't as bad as others in terms of doing several missions that feel exactly the same. You'll still end up chasing down a lot of people, but it's... better some how.
There are some kinks to work out, like running the game in compatability mode was the only way to keep it from looping on the loading screen between missions. The skinny: like every other game in this genre, Sleeping Dogs is plagued with some issues, but for me, it pulls ahead of the pack and is a great game. If you like GTA-type games, you're going to love Sleeping Dogs.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is an open world action game with a twist on melee fighting,
It has a cliche but OK story, great soundtrack, beautiful, detailed depiction of Hong Kong, fun car-handling.

Although very reminiscent of Batman games; the fighting is fluid and really well done for what it is.

Extreme density is absolutely amazing, it really makes Hong Kong come to life.

Yes, you cannot fly. Yes, it does feel quite restricted at times. Yes gunplay is not the best.

Get it for the unique setting these type of games usually lack. I've not played a True Crime game before, but I sure am hoping for a sequel.

The publisher periodically gives great sales, add it on your wishlist, you won't be disappointed, especially at such a low price.

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs is a solid, but sorta clunky, game. I would recommend this game to anyone who likes action/open world games.
First off, I would recommend playing with a controller for this game. The keyboard controls aren't TERRIBLE, but you will be finding yourself fustrated in some fighting/driving sections in the game. Nevertheless, Sleeping Dogs has a fun combat system, similar to the Batman Arkham games. It is smooth and you will be finding yourself just going around Hong Kong beating up baddies.
Hong Kong is spectacular to look at (especially at night). Overall, it is a good looking game. Character models look good and all characters in the game are well voice acted. The characters in Sleeping Dogs are detailed and Wei Shen is a likeable main character along with the other supporting characters in the game.
Hong Kong feels alive, wherever you go it will feel like you are in an actual city that you will be able to explore. Sleeping Dogs also has quite a few side activities including: races, fight clubs, karaoke (yes, karaoke), side challenges, betting on chicken fights and more.
There are quite a few things to collect around Hong Kong. There is actual importance in these collectibles, like to learn to fighting moves or increase your maximum health.
Sleeping Dogs has some issues that shine a little too many times throughout this game. The game is sometimes too easy. In shooter sections, it is just too easy, the AI just isn't smart enough to make you get a game over screen in these sections. And although there is quite a bit of side mission in this game, they kinda get repettitive. Some quests often have you do very similar activities here and there. And this game can be fustratingly buggy. Just be prepared when the game just decides to do a total U-turn on you in some sections like action hijacking a big vehicle for example.
With all of that said, Sleeping Dogs is a decently solid game. I was actually amazed by how much fun I was having when I first played this game. But I recommend Sleeping Dogs to anyone that is looking for an action/ open world game.

reviewText:
After an incident in America where Jackie Chan and Bruce Lee were merged into the same body, Bruce Chan is deported to a foreign wasteland where crime runs rampant and everybody forgot which side of the road to drive on.

10/10
--

In all seriousness, this game's â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing great.  An open-world story that doesn't completely suck, a better undercover cop story than USA Network could ever hope to write, and martial friggin' arts.  In my mind, it doesn't just match GTA-- it dominates it.

An easy recommendation for a personal favorite.  It would have been nice to include the previous version of the game, which runs a bit better, but the Definitive Edition at least includes all DLC (minus the stupid free-money ones) and rebalances them to make them more fair.

It also has Emma Stone, for about two missions before she mysteriously disappears in a strange occurrence known as budget-tosis.""

reviewText:
One day this game went on to Xbox Live for a free game with gold so I decided to get it. It was the original version and this one hadn't come out yet. I loved the game so much, and it was my favorite game. Sadly, my Xbox broke for unknown reasons and I was unable to play the game for a while. Then one day i see that this new and improved version of Sleeping Dogs has been released, and by then I had purchased a gaming PC so I was very exited when I found out I would be able to play Sleeping Dogs once again.
I bought this, downloaded it, and played it. I spent 15 hours playing it on my first day of owning it.

Now, the Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition goes through various improvements from the previous version. I will now go step by step describing them.

Graphical Stuff: 9/10
The trailer boasts about graphical and texture improvements, and they weren't lying. There aren't much improvements to the graphics as there are to the textures. Lighting is very clearly improved and clothing and hair are no longer static. There is a few minor glitches to this kind of things but nothing too noticeable.

Audio: 5/10
I personally cant see much difference.

Gameplay: 8/10
Sleeping Dogs: DE has a few changes to the gameplay. For example, the city of Hong Kong feels much more immersive, there is more pedestrians and traffic making Hong Kong feel more like Hong Kong. The driving mechanics feel much smoother and better. But now for cons. some of the walking controls feel very wonky and sometimes it is more difficult to actually do the parkour in the game. The game is also no longer able to generate everything in your general area, so sometimes you'll take a few step and all of a sudden the game will span a group of civilians right next to Wei. and sometimes people spawn in the sky and fall to Earth. but overall, really good gameplay.

SPOILERS FROM HERE ON!

I love this game so much, the story is amazing and there is so much attachment to characters. I felt bad for Mrs. Chu when Winston died at his wedding, and cried when Wei found Jackie Ma's dead body. When you find that Pendrew was a bad guy I was shocked. So much happens within this game and I hope to never stop playing it

That's why my final rating for this game is 9/10.

reviewText:
THIS GAME HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO BEAT GTA!!!

The game has nice graphics similar to the latest GTA series:GTA V.
However,it has features that GTA doesn't have such as:
-Ability to have multiple vehicles;regardless of cars or motorcycle parked in the parking-lot similar to the mechanics of a garage.
-Martial arts ofc!

It has an interesting story line with the hero being a guy named Wei Shen,an undercover cop situated in Hong Kong and disguised as a gangster to tackle the crimes in HK.It gets interesting as the story goes as Wei slowly meets gang leaders and well,I wouldn't spoil the experience for those who haven't bought this game.IF YOU HAVEN'T BUY THIS GAME YET,BUY IT!!!

Btw,martial arts ftw :D
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
The best singleplayer game I've played in a couple of years.
If you like kung-fu action movies with Jet Li, this game is better.

Scenery is beautiful, full of colours, neons and Chinese atmosphere. Night market with pushy salesmen or Soho at night - aahhh.
The storyline is so addictive, that I played 3-4 hours at once.
Gameplay is fast and intense. In most missions you'll find fight, car chases and shooting. There are also stealth and logic parts, like phone tracking or hacking.
You've to earn reputation to get bonuses, can dress Wei up like you want or learn new kung-fu moves - another big plus.

Only bad thing about it: It's to short. I needed 25 hours to complete main storyline and get most of bonuses.

Rate: 9/10, because I could never play it again for the first time.

reviewText:
Playing Sleeping Dogs kept me on the edge of my seat, but not for the reasons you might expect. Sure, Sleeping Dogsâ€™ melee combat and gunplay provide plenty of thrills, the driving is extraordinarily fun in all of its arcadey glory. But at the end of my nearly 20-hour experience, none of that mattered to me as much as the story did. Itâ€™s that story, coupled with rock-solid mechanics and a task-heavy world that sets Sleeping Dogs apart from its competition.

- I recommend this game and i solemnly pledge that this game is worth your time and money.
-P.S i dont betray my brothers.

reviewText:
WELCOME TO HONG-KONG

This Game Is Fu$%ing Amazing!!!

PROS:
-The Graphics are gorgeous! Especially at night and with this new fog level haha :D
-Gameplay was the most fun part in my opinion because with all the DLC's included you could play with different outfit's witch result in different moves in combat and non-combat! (For example if i switched to the drunked outfit, then i would have the drunken master moves! hell yeah, and if i switch to the cop outfit i can get any car i want from the street withouth being called a thief xD
-The Story was incredible with all the cool missions and friends you get along with :D
-Audio, damn beautiful! I think i spend like 2 hours singing karaoke man, beacause it's just soo cool and Wei voice is perfect for the songs haha :D but not only that, the action, combat, the music,the radio, all of them are beautiful!
-True hong-kong food because you are never a whole man without a pork bun, trust me!
-A ton of sides activities witch are super funny and interesting to do! The cars, girls,massage,poker,races,cop job's and my favorite, dates yeeaahhh...that can take you up to 15-20h without the story included!

Cons:
-You can date girls and speak about sex but never get to see how Wei is getting that A$$ witch kinda sucks i guess  xD
-A couple of weird physics witch are actually funny xD but they aren't that bad at all actually! :)
But that's kinda it about cons i can't see so many reasons why i should do a list about this anyway...the game it's really fun!

I've had a lot of fun with the game and i trully recommend it to people who enjoy a mixed game of gta and saint row with cool Kung Fu Moves and the beautiful world of Hong Kong!

What? You didn't like the review mate? I think you need to grab a Pork Bun and think about buying this game!

12/10 A Must Play Again!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Should you play this game? Yes, and here's why:
-The story is badass and at times very brutal.
-The setting is a busy, gang-ridden urban Hong Kong with lots of bad Chinese English. You can almost smell the dim sum.
-You feel like you're in a Hong Kong crime action film
-The fighting is satisfying enough without being too sensitive.
-Some challenges actually very challenging (beware poison knives challenge)

Some things to be warned:
-At times doing the many side missions can become very reptitive and boring. I have done so many drug busts from the comfort of my home in this game that it felt like checking the mail.
-The models of NPCs don't vary much, especially the street gang members. It really took away from the big city feel beating up the same guys wearing the same clothes everywhere.
-Though it took me 40 hours to go through this game at a leisurely gaming pace (doing side missions as I pleased, not investing too much into beating the game), I felt like the middle lacked depth. The bread on the sandwich was good, but the meat was old and dry.

TLDR; Good Story. Repetitive. Get it on sale only.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Excellent game, despite a few minor bugs that ended up being more funny than irritating (climbed a wooden fence with another fence behind it and ended up floating Matrix jump-kick style for a few minutes until I could get unstuck!)

Storyline was amazing, progression was pretty much by choice (whether you wanted to rush through or take your time doing side missions and finding secrets), combat was super fun and satisfying, both with the guns and kung fu. One minor downside was the dating side missions. At first I thought they would be a bit deeper, but most of them are just 1 or 2 missions and then nothing ever again. I also found it hilarious that one of the missions was to find out if one of the girls you end up dating was cheating on you, even though you're pretty much dating 3 women at the same time by this point.

After the mess that was Final Fantasy 13, I was ready to basically give up on Square Enix, but this game most definitely boosted my confidence in their abilities.

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
An extremely enjoyable open world game that has incredible lighting and effects, and enjoyable story and a vivid, lively open world hongkong that makes you feel as if you have stepped into hong kong yourself.

Sleeping dogs has incredible graphics for its age (mind you, the difinitive edition only added denser crowds, breakable objects and inproved lighting to the original 2012 release), and the city of hong kong feels alive, with the beautiful night markets with neon signs to the city centre and the densely packed pedestrians, who speak either english, cantonese or a mix. of course with today's technoloogy, we can do so much better, so keep your fingers crossed for a sequel.

Well to the story. Its pretty well written, and do contain some surprises, and you can really feel the tension between Wei and his police handlers. Its a shame how you do not get a choice of how the story goes, but the ending is pretty dark, and does show the emotional deaths, betrayal and decisions wei makes in the end.

Another problem with the game, the developers used too many stereotypes. For example, some of the npcs in the game have such a heavy chinese accent (true, some do, but not all) and some of events in the game feels like its taken from a typical hong kong film (though the game is supposed to have the hong kong martial arts movie feel). The map is big, but of course there are still areas that are inaccessible, and i hope they do create a sequel with a larger, more lifelike hong kong.

The fighting and environmental kills do offer a unique taste to the game, and the bullet time when shooting and driving is well done. But some of the controls feel sluggish sometimes, and this game is not without some bugs and glitches which either cause your game to crash or force you to restart the mission.

I would give this game an 8/10. a severely underrated game. oh have i mentioned that this game has better hacking than watch_dogs (better, but watchdogs have alot more). Its a bargain to buy this game, especially during steam sales. With its success in its formula, i have a feeling the developers could not be working on an actual sequal (or maybe with a new character), since they game up on triad wars.

reviewText:
First of all, let me say, this game looks freaking awesome. If you have the horsepower to run it, that is. Otherwise you are going to be stuck with something not quite as awesome.

Pros/cons:

+ Awesome graphics
+ Overall strong storyline with occasional weak points.
+ Strong gameplay, strong fighting mechanics
- No real consequence (moral or otherwise) of choices, linear storyline
- Weak gunplay
- Sometimes inresponsive controls
- Single button for everything (freerun,climb,etc). Goddamit. It's annoying

Recommendation: Get it if you like GTA-style games.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs, I must say, is one of the best story-driven sandbox RPG game I have played so far. In addition, Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition brought the game to its near maximum potential due to its graphics update and the whole environment that have been added into the game. Certain physics and other stuff have been implemented as well to add realness and finesse as you play trough it:

- Hair, clothes, and boob physics (cause, why not) :3
- More people = more carnage
- More vibrant atmosphere in various places
- 1080p goodness

Annoying/recurring bugs:

- Sudden sfx loss (when riding a boat or using a certain type of vehicle)
- Counter mechanics is still a bit clunky (in my opinion) but alot more responsive than it used to.
- Certain glitch occurence (i.e Zodiac Tournament).

There might not be alot of changes, but it is certain that Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition have captured the Hong Kong experience once more.

reviewText: The definitive edition plays just as well, if not slightly better than the original, but what really sets this version apart from the already excellent vanilla edition is the fact that Hong Kong actually looks like Hong Kong this time. Many may prefer the slick neon, (and very Western) vision of Hong Kong from the original game, but the muted colours, haze, and lighting in the DE all help to present a Hong Kong that is much more faithful to that great city. If only the game offered more opportunities to beat up corrupt police and Beijing officials.. - 9/10

reviewText:
One of my favourite open world game of all time.

Pros :
- The combat system is a lot of fun with those street fistfights. But BEWARE for you who love gunfights, you are not able to buy any gun freely. Guns in this game are only available through several special missions and legendary costume shops (when you bought some costumes like agent 47 costume, you will automatically equipped with a gun).
- The parkour run in this game is just perfect. It makes the game more charming and gives you more variations to run away from cops or hostiles.
- There are many cool vehicles and costumes to collect. I usually wear that Rico Rodriguez costume to spam those grenade launchers.
- Badass main character, good voice actings, many memorable scenes & great story.
- There are a lot of missions to complete and each mission is different from the others. The missions are not repetitive and makes me want to try them all (which I did).
- Destructable environment, normal for an open world like this.
- You can develop your character by learning and upgrading his skills (cop skills, triad skills, melee fighting skills) and even his health bar.
- Talking about skill, there's this skill that allows you to enter a slow motion mode similar to Max Payne 3.
- Sometimes, we are a bit annoyed bt the fact that there's no vehicle nearby when we need it the most. Don't worry, there's a VALET PARK feature, but there's a special requirement for that. You can call your driver anytime (except during quest), anywhere (except if you are standing in places that unaccessable by cars or motorcycles) to deliver your vehicles to your exact location.

Cons :
- I'm not sure whether this is a cons or not. The amount of weapons in this game is a bit lacking, especially for guns. That's probably because this game's charm is the fistfights, not gunfights. The other explanation is there will be stated in the story that guns are rare in Hongkong. If we can access guns easily like in GTA or Saints Row, those martial art fighting skills will be useless.
- If you equip a gun, you cannot interact with some NPCs like food selling NPCs or Parking NPCs because they are afraid of you. This is supported by the guns in Hongkong are rare" logic. Oh
recommended: if you equipped yourself with a weapon

votesTotal: etc can broke in battle. You simply can't keep them for long in this game. Your fist is your loyal weapon.\n- Camera is a bit troublesome when driving
votesFunny: sometimes.\n\nOverall
commentsCount: this game gave me great experience and immersion. I feel like a total badass in this game.\n9/10. Worth the price

reviewText:
Modern Review for an older game.

I had recently picked this up and I had always wanted the game from when I was a consol peasent playing on a xbox 360. The games graphics arn't the greatest and I had experienced one glitch in a full 3 hours of gameplay so it has matured expectedly.

The plot is very liear, keep that in mind. this isn't a do whatever rpg like skyrim.

The last mention for this is that this game does everything all at once. I mean everything. you play as a cop who gets to bust drug deals, you get to race cars, you get to do gears of war shooting mechanics, you get platformer style fighting in a 3rd person enviorment. you get gta style open world car driving.

it has alot of potential (note: Im saying this in late 2015) the concept was great I wish they could do a re make or a sequal to fix all the problems. because its too liear, they didn't focus enough on cars, they didn't make a proper shooting aspect that was noteable, they didnt't make the plot memorable. All of these things could be fixed in a sequal I wish they would make one because at its core I really like the game.

reviewText: An excellent sandbox game, with fantastic atmosphere and feeling.\n\nSleeping Dogs is a sandbox action-adventure game set in Hong Kong. You play as Wei Shen, a police officer sent on an undercover assignment to infiltrate the Triads. The story is great, with fantastic mission variety and stellar voice acting by a cast of well known Hollywood actors. Characters are developed pretty well, and you can really feel ther emotions. However, due to the nature of the story, it could have benefited more from a sort of trust" system like Splinter Cell Double Agent had. Here

reviewText: Now that I've finished the game, I'm qualified to make a review on it. The game starts off with an awesome scene where you run away from the cops, you are captured and you are in jail with Jackie he then takes you to a fight area where you learn combat moves and more. The combat system is really similar to Rocksteady's Batman Arkham franchise in many ways. There are awesome car chases with guns, like when you capture Naz. The game features more things than Grand Theft Auto EX: Shooting while driving, Karaoke, Face Level, Cop Missions, Triad Missions, Door slam, and more! I really like the Defenitive Edition, I had the original one on Xbox 360 and I played it for hours and hours on end. I played this for days and days. The graphics are great on the next gen!

reviewText:
One of the best open world games I've ever played, though it does suffer from a few problems.

First off, there are still a few bugs that are present in the game, a few of which prevented me from completing missions and making me restart the entire mission (Sometimes there would be an invisible thug that I couldn't beat in order to progress, the person I was chasing disappeared, etc.).  but these didn't happen too often. There also appears to be an issue with vsync, as screen tearing is still very apparent even with vsync on.

The driving is fun, but sometimes the game makes you take some ridiculously long routes to missions.

Other than these things, it's still a really fun game, very good looking, and overall an experience that I enjoyed.

I didn't toucht the DLCs too much, they seemed kinda silly which isn't something I like with this kind of game.

reviewText:
You play as Wei Shen, an undercover police officer who's on a case of destabilizing the triad of Hong Kong.
One could say it's GTA with a chinese flair.

PROS:

+ great story
+ outstanding voice acting and fleshed out characters
+ diverse and unique main and side missions
+ the epic chicken fight(trust me, you'll understand once you get there)

CONS:

- the GPS is often going batshit crazy
- the side missions can get a bit repetitive after a while
- the freeruning in the city is an illusion, rendering HK a bit shallow explorationwise

Generally, I dislike chinese settings in games and films.
They simply don't click with me.
Which is why Sleeping Dogs was such a nice surprise.
The game is enjoyable, feels smooth, has its own character, presents the player
with an awesome action-filled content.
I could say that it lacks depth and replayability, but it's not a huge issue.
You'll definitely have fun while it lasts.

reviewText: Grand Theft Auto-like gameplay in a Hong Kong setting. It excels in taking its setting to heart, with lots of gorgeous city lights and aiming for mainly hand-to-hand combat as its core gameplay mechanic (as guns are hard to find in Hong Kong, obviously). That being said, the amount of gunplay that there is in the game is rather terrible. It seems since that isn't the core mechanic, they didn't feel it necessary to put much effort into making it feel good. Nevertheless, that hindrance is limited, and the majority of the game is a joy to play.

reviewText:
One of my favourite open world game of all time.

Pros :
- The combat system is a lot of fun with those street fistfights. But BEWARE for you who love gunfights, you are not able to buy any gun freely. Guns in this game are only available through several special missions and legendary costume shops (when you bought some costumes like agent 47 costume, you will automatically equipped with a gun).
- The parkour run in this game is just perfect. It makes the game more charming and gives you more variations to run away from cops or hostiles.
- There are many cool vehicles and costumes to collect. I usually wear that Rico Rodriguez costume to spam those grenade launchers.
- Badass main character, good voice actings, many memorable scenes & great story.
- There are a lot of missions to complete and each mission is different from the others. The missions are not repetitive and makes me want to try them all (which I did).
- Destructable environment, normal for an open world like this.
- You can develop your character by learning and upgrading his skills (cop skills, triad skills, melee fighting skills) and even his health bar.
- Talking about skill, there's this skill that allows you to enter a slow motion mode similar to Max Payne 3.
- Sometimes, we are a bit annoyed bt the fact that there's no vehicle nearby when we need it the most. Don't worry, there's a VALET PARK feature, but there's a special requirement for that. You can call your driver anytime (except during quest), anywhere (except if you are standing in places that unaccessable by cars or motorcycles) to deliver your vehicles to your exact location.

Cons :
- I'm not sure whether this is a cons or not. The amount of weapons in this game is a bit lacking, especially for guns. That's probably because this game's charm is the fistfights, not gunfights. The other explanation is there will be stated in the story that guns are rare in Hongkong. If we can access guns easily like in GTA or Saints Row, those martial art fighting skills will be useless.
- If you equip a gun, you cannot interact with some NPCs like food selling NPCs or Parking NPCs because they are afraid of you. This is supported by the guns in Hongkong are rare" logic. Oh
recommended: if you equipped yourself with a weapon

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs

This one is good. You are an undercover HKPD agent who is tasked with infiltrating the ranks of the Triad Gangs, in order to exact some justice. Along the way, you make choices; you face tough decisions and you become immersed in a alternate reality form of Hong Kong. The city is riddled with violent gangs (unlike the real Hong Kong) and as a HKPD officer, you have to weigh in decisions of going dirty or doing it by the law. The graphics are more PC-worthy, with my only complaint being, that the SSAO is actually not that appealing. What makes this different from GTA and GTA clones, is that it emphasizes the use of martial arts in combat, instead of melee weapons and guns. You do have access to melee weapons and guns, but they are not the do-all be-all of the game. I do praise the adoption of native cantonese language which bears similarity to what you hear in Hong Kong; there are of course, optional english subtitles for those who need them.

There is some touches of humor, but the story and dialogue is more on a serious level. There are minigames such as karaoke (reminds me of a form of guitar hero or audiosurf), you can do police missions or triad missions, you can buy cheap and really nice cars and keep them in a garage; you can call a valet or taxi driver. Also, thanks to the definitive edition: You can max out the crowd density, which depicts a more accurate Hong Kong instead of the older console version which was optimized for old consoles. You will pick up the fact that the map of Hong Kong in this game isn't a 100% accurate match of the real Hong Kong, the roads are different and the island is the primary location. There are some places which bear resemblance to Hong Kong, (like victoria peak); but other than that the designers did some embellishing to fit the story, which is fine in my opinion.

All in all, I recommend this game for those who like open-city martial arts GTA style games. The story is good and the gameplay is entertaining, with a certain amount of replay value.

Now, instead of giving pros and cons; I will give the recipe to pork buns. Why? So you can become a whole man, duh!

reviewText: The graphics in this game are stellar. The fighting mechanic works well and provides plenty of opportunity for brutal action. Very well animated all around, with a cool story to keep things moving along. I don't like dressing up in the dorky cop uniform, but those missions do provide a nice change of pace. It's natural to compare this to GTA games. The crisp controls of Sleeping Dogs makes GTA feel sluggish in comparison. It's this natural feel of the game that had me spending a lot of time enjoying this open world. I do miss the guns, explosions, and silly â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ in GTA. When I want that stuff, I'll pop over to GTA for 5 minutes, then come back to Sleeping Dogs for the next hour or so.

reviewText:
It's like a good Jet Li movie, with a well written and imersive story.

The combat is especially fun and it I never got bored pumelling random inconsequential foes, which I can't say the same for many other po-faced cookie cutter sandboxes.

The great storyline missions aside, the generous variety of side quests feel rewarding to complete for the most part, with very little filler and fetch quests to waste your time with.

I could hardly flaw this game, a refreshing experience in an ocean of mediocrity.

reviewText:
A very good and fun GTA clone. A good story to enjoy, lots of gore and hard violence.
Crisp and sharp  graphics ( and I say it as an owner of an old machine) , cool music and interesting main story make up for some repetitive missions.
Missions are involve most of the time driving and hand to hand combat.
Sometimes challenging, but far from a hard game, SE is, in the bottom line, a fun game to play with a protagonist (Wei Shen) to remember.
Year of the snake" addition is forgetable
date: just adds more of the same if you played it after playing main game (which makes sense logically/chronically
recommended: but then you get items for it... go figure.)

reviewText:
I voted yes to recommend this game, but I gave up on it after 15 hours, why?...

Graphis are beautiful, the characters are extremely detailed, animations are great.

The combat is amazing, highly addicting!

The story is good and engages you enough that you want to see it through.

So what killed it for me?

Driving...

Just the thought of having to drive to another location made me cringe, and thinking of doing any of the driving missions or racing side quests made me nauseous.

The driving is atrocious.. to compare it with other driving/open world" games:

GTA has one of the best driving.

Just Cause 2 is worse than GTA

Sleeping Dogs hits rock bottom.

If you feel you can get past this and bare with driving from point A to point B to engage in amazing combat

reviewText:
Better than ever! I owned the original and I have a special relationship with this game. It was the first game that I bought, installed, and played after building my first rig. But that aside...

The controls are better and it seems that you have access to police vehicles earlier. Those may have originally been part of DLC's from the original but Im not sure. (Specifically I am talking about the HKPD SUV). The non-police vehicle that I just got very early on was something that I dont remember at all, the custom van with the air-brushed dragons on it. Im not complaining. Actually it makes getting around easier.

The textures on Wei look better. However, the actual world itself doesnt seem to be any different than the original with the HD Texture pack isntalled. The devs say its actually better but I cant really see a difference.

But if you have never played this game then you have to get it. You wont regret it. This is everything that Grand Theft Auto wishes it could be and never was. Nor can GTA ever be this good because they have gone too extreme in their stupidity.

reviewText: At first, it certainly does appear to be inspired by Rockstarâ€™s Grand Theft Auto series, with protagonist Wei Shen thrown into a life of crime and asked to do horrendous things to progress the plot. But quickly it reveals itself to be much more than that. Early on it's explained that Shen is actually an undercover cop, sent into Hong Kong to climb the ranks of the Triads and take them down from the inside, creating a conflicted protagonist that's easy to sympathize with.\n\nSleeping Dogs is a fun and forward-thinking sandbox game. The missions may be samey, but the core experience is varied and enjoyable. Great stuff.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Sleeping Dogs brings a unique take to the overexploited open-world theme. An exciting (although sometimes repetitive) game mechanism that relies heavily on well-choreographed hand-to-hand combat and sudden quick time events. Input recognition needs some work for the PC adaption, but overall a smooth experience. A strong, gripping story that keeps you on your toes for the entirety of the game, not to mention tons of side quests and customization options that keep you playing for a long time after the curtain closes. Character dialogue and voicing very well done, with plenty of comedy thrown in for good measure. 9.5/10

reviewText:
The game is my guilty pleasure. TL;DR is on the bottom
It's way too underrated and imo it's better than some of the games that the AAA publishers release now like a diarrhea on our plates when we were expecting something delicious (I'm looking at you, watch_dogs).
You are basically a guy from Hong Kong that visited America and now came back. You are recruited as an undercover cop and have to work with a triad along with your friend and other people. There comes the plot, which is very well written and kept me interested when I wasn't putting people's heads into saw tables.
The fighting is very fun and satisfying. There is also cover-based shooting, which is not necessary a bad thing - mostly because it doesn't overuse it. The game has great amount of detail and AMAZING atmosphere.
It also has hacking minigames, which most ironically are better than hacking in watch_dogs, which is a game focused on hacking. There aren't much collectibles, sadly - a thing I enjoy in sandboxes a lot.
The game does Ride to hell: Retribution kind of thing where you go on a date and you bang her.
However, people at United Front Games aren't 12 year old immature idiots, so it's off camera.
Speaking of cameras, there is a side-mission where you beat up some thugs, hack the camera in the same area and go back to your house. When you do that, you access the camera view and choose which guy is a drug dealer, thus he has to go with the nice men with guns to a building where people come in a lot but don't seem to come out so much.
Remember when I said about putting people's heads into saw tables? There is a lot of environment kills which are nicely varied and fun. Some of them are brutal, like cutting someone's head in half in an air vent, and some of them are silly, like drowning someone in his own p1ss. These are just two, but there are quite a lot. You can get melee weapons in cars and next to your enemy's dead body if he had one, but they break after few hits.
But of course, what would be a good third-person sandbox without drivingcough cough Batman: Arkham City cough cough? There is one guy with a magical ability to teleport between the points you can get your own cars. You get new cars by side-missions, races and buying them if you're the rich kid. You can also ''borrow'' cars from the citizens, just like a thief ''borrows'' your money and a serial killer ''borrows'' your life. People who were once behind Need For Speed (if I'm not mistaken) were programming the car controls and they make me moist. The driving is fun and with an ability to ram into people's stuff the developers threw reality out of the window and nicely welcomed fun into their house - something that the AAA publishers treat like the ultimate sin. However, with a button to open your car's door and jump out of onto another person's car they asked fun to help them hang reality and hit it with a baseball bat like a pinata. As I mentioned earlier there are races which are fun and rewarding. You get money and Face Experience points for winning a race, but some of them give you outfits or new cars. Oh, I think I forgot to mention the leveling system.
You basically got three experience bars: Triad XP, Cop XP and Face XP. Both of Triad and Cop XP have 2 upgrade paths.
You can only get Triad XP in main missions. The more gruesome you are, the more you get. Cop XP can be received in main-missions as well, but also side-missions. If you don't kill anyone innocent and do no property damage in a main-mission or side-mission, you get more XP. The Face XP allows you to get more things that you can wear to have small yet balanced bonuses and give various upgrades as well. Another upgrade tree is the combos you can do. In one of the missions you go with a girl to a kung-fu school that you were once a student of. Your teacher teaches you one combo for free and then asks you to get his lost statues back. For each one of them, you get a new combo of your choice and if you get all of them, you get an advanced counter move. The basic counter is OP by itself, so now you're basically the Thor of Hong Kong. If you like references, then you will enjoy that aspect as well. For example, there is a yellow jumpsuit referencing a movie starring Bruce Lee. Almost every enemy is dressed in a suit or in something that a young teen would consider ''cool'', so killing them in a bright yellow jumpsuit that can probably kill them just because of how intense the color is can never not be fun. I know I said the word ''fun'' a lot in this review of mine, so if you ever want to read this whole wall of text remember to take a shot every time I mention the word ''fun''. Warning: I don't take the responsibility of you dropping dead.
TL;DRGet the game and don't ask questions - especially when it's on sale.

reviewText: I am a fan of open world action games so i think this game deliver that atmosphere very well. I only played definitive so i am not sure what they added the game but i can say it's pretty solid game. Unlike other series this game is heavily on hand to hand combat rather then guns or tools. Driving gets a little time to adapt. Combat is amazing. Missions and side missions are fun to play. Integrated dlc missions is also fun to play. For the story at first i didn't like the idea of being a undercover cop (thought they will restirct my actions) it didn't matter and the story development was pretty good. But i think they could give a better feeling about Wei's pressure about being undercover or never mention it. Despite all that Wei Shen is a true man and you know why because he eats pork bun..

reviewText:
Holy hell, this game is good, finished the main story line within 16 hours including a couple of the side missions. I'm hooked and can't wait to play some more side missions and do some cop jobs. The story was really interesting and made me abandon any social life I had prior to me clicking the play button on the game.

It really is worth investing time into this game, it starts off simple as a little foot soldier for the Sun on Yee at the night market as an undercover officer which then leads to the boss of the gang you're in respecting you and getting you a promotion, you then advance through the triad on a perilous and profoundly action packed adventure.

Even though I finished the story line, there is tons of side missions and events that I have missed and are set for me to do now.

9/10 - (It would feel like I'm exaggerating if I put down 10/10 so I put 9, but really I mean a 10 ;-;).

reviewText: I didn't think this was my my kind of game, but I decided to try it anway when it was on a good sale. I'm so glad I did. It's a lot of fun. There's driving. There's shooting. There's martial arts. There's a really good story. There's a ridiculous body count. Maybe most importantly, there's one of my favorite ever open-world environments. This is a great game and I feel that it's a must have. The game's story is one of the best and I have felt attactched to the characters of the game. The gameplay and game mechanics are awesome and unique and the graphics are good even with todays standards (granted this is a remastered edition). My only problem with this game is it is a little too short with a little over 10 hours for me and the cliff hanger didnt satisfy me I wanted to know what would happen afterwords (heres to hoping they make sleeping dogs 2 one day).

All together I think if you havent played the orginal version of this game then its a must have.

reviewText:
This game is gruesome in an all-too-good way. If you want an actually biting and well-engineered game with the message that crime doesn't pay, play this game. It demonstrates exactly why the criminal lifestyle is bad without forcing it down your throat or completely jerking your chain like GTA4 does. You lose friends - emotionally and literally - you make enemies, you suffer, you bleed, you break, you hurt, and some things you just have to let go in order to live. Hong Kong is a beautiful and mean place, and you get to find out first-hand just how terrible it can be to be a gangster.

Visually and audibly this game is absolutely beautiful even despite the dicky optimization on PC, and its gameplay is so satisfying and free-feeling even when you're just blitzing main quests like I did my first time around. The first time you roll around the neon-lit Hong Kong at night while listening to chilled out electronic tracks on Ninja Tune will take your breath away, I guarantee it.

Story-wise, the story can be a BIT spotty, but it's hardly gaping with holes and it's easy to suspend your disbelief to understand them. The developers seemed to actually care about the fact that you might want to cut loose and plough through a shopping district sometimes after a hard mission, so you only get punished for murder through police attention and, if you're on a mission, reduced Cop XP rather than revoking money or XP retroactively.

The characters are also REALLY likeable and surprisingly memorable even with such a wide cast. You will learn to love Jackie Ma, you will learn to loathe Dogeyes, and you will learn to breathe like Wei Shen.

Hong Kong is a cruel place, but it's also a beautiful place.
This game makes me want to visit it for real.
Do not pass up your chance to play this, if you ever get it.

reviewText: At first, it certainly does appear to be inspired by Rockstarâ€™s Grand Theft Auto series, with protagonist Wei Shen thrown into a life of crime and asked to do horrendous things to progress the plot. But quickly it reveals itself to be much more than that. Early on it's explained that Shen is actually an undercover cop, sent into Hong Kong to climb the ranks of the Triads and take them down from the inside, creating a conflicted protagonist that's easy to sympathize with.\n\nSleeping Dogs is a fun and forward-thinking sandbox game. The missions may be samey, but the core experience is varied and enjoyable. Great stuff.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Sleeping Dogs brings a unique take to the overexploited open-world theme. An exciting (although sometimes repetitive) game mechanism that relies heavily on well-choreographed hand-to-hand combat and sudden quick time events. Input recognition needs some work for the PC adaption, but overall a smooth experience. A strong, gripping story that keeps you on your toes for the entirety of the game, not to mention tons of side quests and customization options that keep you playing for a long time after the curtain closes. Character dialogue and voicing very well done, with plenty of comedy thrown in for good measure. 9.5/10

reviewText:
Sleeping dogs
Another Square Enix special
about the game
Sleeping dogs is third person open world game

pros
+amazing graphic
+great fight system (collecting special statues you unlocking special moves)
+primary quest are marked green for Triads  and blue for Police
+lots of side: racing, favors, martial arts clubs ( each of them help you build you Face level)
+nice cars and bikes each of them are in classes, ( finishing races you can get a tuned car as reward)
+great wardrobe system : lots of set clothes with bonuses on damage, triad or police  bonus, also discounts on vehicles
+awesome weather effects (you can actually see the rain on road)
+the main story is very interesting
+police chase system is pretty interesting: pretty hard to escape if you want to race but pretty easy if you want to destroy them by ramming


cons
-driving a car or bike  on very high speed you lose handling and its 99% to crash

my rate for sleeping dogs 8/10
and does this game worth 30 euros 10/10
and its from Square Enix so thats should tell you all 10/10

reviewText:
I love Sleeping Dogs, I had 200+ hrs of gameplay in Sleeping Dogs (standard non-steam). And after having played both of them I can say that the Definitive Edition was completely unnecessary. Here's why I didn't like it...

-Character controls feel even sloppier now.

-Very little noticeable changes in the graphics and textures, almost everything seem the same as they were in the original Sleeping Dogs. I don't see the point in spending money for the little graphical improvements.

-It's so freakin' bright, especially indoors during the daytime, so much that I feel like it's going to give me a migraine attack.

-The vehicles controls in races are more terrible in the definitve edition. Bike races are the worst, this time the opponents will try to push you off the track everytime you try cut them off.

-It would be a lie to say that the game doesn't have any bugs.

-You don't get the all black attire you got in the last mission of the original game that was later part of the High Roller DLC pack so that players can have access to it from the beginning of the story. It's not there anymore, instead you get a gray one now. Seriously, what asian gangster doesn't own a black suit, it's almost their trademark, don't you think?


I don't know why players should buy this one instead of the original Sleeping Dogs. I know you can't get it on steam anymore, but steam isn't the only place you could get the standard edition from. Try the trade section on the steamgifts website, some traders do have copies of the original one up for trade.

reviewText:
OLD DOG, NO NEW TRICKS

â†’ OCTOBER 8, 2014 Many open-world, non-linear drive-and-gun games -- with some notable exclusions -- tend to tack on a story merely to loosely justify whatever it is you're doing. But the main thing I made clear in my original review of Sleeping Dogs on Xbox 360 and PS3 back in 2012 is that while it's a blast to play, its story is actually the star of the show. The Definitive Edition for new-gen consoles carries over both of those great traits and adds a decent facelift, and it's just as fun and just as memorable as it was the first time around. An engaging plot littered with memorable characters and a ton of slowly building tension is artfully coupled with solid melee action, gunplay, and driving to create a multi-faceted game that satisfies on all fronts.

As far as the aesthetic is concerned, Sleeping Dogs was never an exceptionally pretty game, but The Definitive Edition resolves some of its biggest visual faults and brings it more
Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition

Inspired by classic Hollywood and Asian cinema style action thrillers, Sleeping Dogs follows the story of detective Wei Shen as he infiltrates one of Hong Kong's notorious Triad crime syndicates.

â†’ MUCH MORE
in line with the PC version. On the Xbox One version I played, draw distances are vastly extended, textures are much sharper, and the overall gloss of the entire convincing recreation of Hong Kong is improved. It doesn't look like a native new-gen game by any stretch of the imagination, however - and itâ€™s disappointing that the framerate stutters a bit when you're on foot running around and exploring, and the camera is still a bit messy in certain circumstances.
Again, though, I have to sing the praises of the story. Sleeping Dogs revolves around an undercover Hong Kong detective named Wei Shen. Shen â€“ who's voiced wonderfully by Will Yun Lee in both English and Cantonese, is an interesting protagonist, one with true depth. Shenâ€™s embedded himself with the Hong Kong underworld in order to unravel it from within, and watching him get sucked further and further into peril is fascinating. He's not a nameless hero or a loosely constructed anyman. He seems as real as a character in a movie.
Of course, Sleeping Dogs has plenty for you if story isn't your thing. Its driving mechanics are on-point, with lots of different vehicles toting unique feels, from run-down motorcycles and hulking industrial trucks to supped-up sedans and expensive sports cars, and everything in between. Developer United Front Games has crafted a believable and incredibly busy version of Hong Kong that's simply a blast to drive around, explore, and uncover. Likewise, fighting -- whether with your fists, a melee weapon, or a firearm -- is also a lot of fun. There's a ton of collectibles to discover in addition to its meaty campaign, with tons of offshoot side quests to complete. In short, Sleeping Dogs is bound to keep you very busy not only when keeping up with its story, but in simply doing everything within it there is to do.

Content-wise, the only notable difference between the old-gen version of Sleeping Dogs and the Definitive Edition is the inclusion of DLC. Both the supernatural-themed Nightmare in North Point and the cop-centric Year of the Snake are included, though I wasn't blown away by either. These separate packs -- which feel disjointed and aren't a part of the campaign -- don't stack up with the likes of GTA IVâ€™s The Lost and the Damned or The Ballad of Gay Tony in terms of the amount of content, the quality of the new characters, or even new objectives. But, it's pretty cool that they're here in case you want to mess with them.
Testing out Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition reminded me of a facet I hadn't thought much about since I last played it in 2012: its multi-tiered leveling system. This experience rubric provides Shen with rewards in three different categories: as a cop, as a member of the criminal Triad, and as a citizen of Hong Kong. Earning experience points in these three categories often conflicts with one another, and each category has unique skills associated with it. Delving into this system is a ton of fun, and it's really cool watching Shen get stronger based on how I chose to behave. Displaying disregard for the citizens of Hong Kong won't net you much love in your Face meter, for instance, but upholding the law will surely bring you plenty of cop experience points.
Amazon	$24.99
Trending Videos

THE VERDICT

Back in 2012, I called Sleeping Dogs one of the biggest -- and most pleasant -- surprises of the year. Two years later, the surprise has obviously dissipated, but that doesn't take away from what United Front Games achieved here. Playing the Definitive Edition reminded me how much I enjoyed its excellent story and characters, combat, and city, but also made me pine for a true new-gen sequel. The differences here might not be worth paying for a second time, but if you missed out on this great open-world action game the first time, you shouldnâ€™t repeat that mistake.

Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition PC
8.5

reviewText:
Odd timing for a sale, assuming you know what else is going on right now. Just bought this version about 2 weeks ago, for about $30.00. I have to say Sleeping Dogs is one of the best games I've ever played and this version is worth your money if you've never played it before. Anyway, I would defiantly pick it up at the current price for certain; Especially given it's under $10 dollars at the moment. Sort of wish I had waited now, ;).

Gameplay is a 9 out of 10. (Bugs in the parkour, missions, etc... hurt this title at times.)
Story is a 8 out of 10 but a 10 out of 10 for a video game.
Audio is 10 out of 10.
Performance is 4 to 8 out of 10 depending upon your system specs. (This doesn't run like the original.)

I have issues with United Front at the moment due to a game they're creating called Triad Wars, so keep in mind there's some personal bias behind my words. It's an issue that will resolve in time but they're making a bad move in my opinion at the moment.

YOU MAY NOT WANT TO BUY THIS GAME IF YOU HAVE THE ORIGINAL!!!
I've bought this game 3 times now, once on PS3, once on PC and again now on PC for the 'Definitive Edition'. From what I can tell: They added fog, may have tweaked the graphics a bit, and seriously f'd the performance up. You'll be probably be disappointed with this as such. They changed up the DLC and you can't remove any of it without hacking it out. This is major issue for some of us (I don't care about that myself.). You also have to buy and/or unlock things now as you progress threw the game. 2 of the DLC's are missing for certain despite what they state, more depending upon which system you came from. (Wasn't a fan of the those anyway and wont list them.)

reviewText:
- An open world action game Ã  la Grand Theft Auto, only this time you're not the criminal but the cop. Follow the storyline, engage in side activities and explore the city of Hong Kong in all of its beauty with the updated graphics from the Definitive Edition equaling ensured entertainment.


Review score: Essential Purchase


â‡“ Personal Review â‡“


Pro Beautiful world design & atmosphere
Good story
Updated graphics
(Limited) character customization
Plenty of side objectives/activities
Includes DLC
Con Vehicle handling
Weapon combat
Small visual bugs from time to time
Some DLC parts might not have received the full graphical update
StorySet in the beautiful city of Hong Kong officer Wei Shen is tasked to bring down the local Triad gang Sun On Yee as an uncercover cop. He gets introduced into the mafia by his old friend Jackie Ma from where he starts working his way up to the top of the criminal circuit. Wei Shen is a loyal person, that loyalty brings him into trouble in both sides of the law because trying to do good takes it toll and possibly his sanity.

The story is well written and ensures that the protagonist doesn't climb up in the ranks too fast in an unrealistic manner. Obviously you shouldn't expect the drama, character relations and humor known from the GTA franchises in this game. Simply because this game depicts how it feels like to survive in a triad gang, not how to save your marriage or how to setup your own drug empire in the middle of a desert.


GraphicsWith the Definitive Edition this game received a graphical update and boy does it show. If you ever want to visit Hong Kong, play this game first. Not that it will be a perfect tour guide, but it really captivates the atmosphere of this asian city with its many districts. Clean and modern looking in 'downtown' area, flashy neon signs and dense ugly looking high-rises in the poorer parts of the city and the many houseboats docked at the docking area. While playing this game I often felt like I was playing in a living, breathing world. That's something I didn't always have while playing a GTA game. Sure I've never been in Hong Kong or any asian city, but after playing this game it kinda feels like I did.

The graphical update also shows during cutscenes where it looks like this game is actually just two years old instead of the original four. There can be some graphical glitches here and there, i.e. npc's popping in/out of screen in front of your face and certain visual effects not always appearing while driving vehicles. But nothing too troublesome.


GameplayI only played this game with a controller so I can't give any input on how it feels with mouse and keyboard. In general I'm very positive about it although there are some points which did annoy me. First off the driving mechanics could be better, even while playing with a controller I have to tab my stick constantly while making larger turns instead of one fluid movement. Bikes have a larger turning radius than cars and driving a car backwards is like driving on ice. But you'll get used to it eventually and thus won't be as big of a problem than in the beginning.

The combat in this game is clearly pointed towards melee combat. Reason being that in the triad culture most fights are fought with bare hands and less with fire arms like we're used to in the west. There are a lot of fighting moves to learn and they all transition perfectly with each other when fighting. The downside to this is that the weapon combat not as refined as in other games.

reviewText:
This game is very fun. I like the story, the graphics and the combat. Driving is very hard at the beginning of the game, but you'll get used to it. About the Combat: I like the special attacks and the shooting is not very good but it isn't bad, just.....  you know.....  normal.
Conclusion: I recommend that you buy this game in a sale. I payed â‚¬7,50 for this awesome game.

My rating: 8.5/10

reviewText:
Sleeping Dogs might just be a better GTA-style game than the GTA series itself. Now maybe it's just the location, but my oh my, Hong Kong is a lively and beautiful setting contrary to Los Santos in GTA V. Lights, cars, people... everywhere. However, what this game lacks is traffic. That might sounds stupid, but traffic, in my eyes, helps to convey the atmosphere of a busy city, as a New Yorker myself. Mind you this is only a personal request and the lack of which does not take away much. Traffic or no traffic, Hong Kong is still amazing.

Speaking of beauty, the textures, for the most part, are very detailed. I say for the most part because often you will find a stray texture that looks horrid in comparison to the ones around it, such as the door to Wei's apartment, as an example. The models for the main characters look great, especially when you can appreciate them up-close in real-time cutscenes. The voice-acting is great too, but the facial animations are pretty mediocre. Lips are synchronized and that's great and all, but the rest of the facial muscles aren't very expressive. Lighting effects convey a vibrant and realistic setting and the reflections are accurate and organic. And the rain.. (OH THE BEAUTIFUL RAIN)... I cannot get enough of the rain, let's just say that. Colors, wetness, all around me... I like it ( Í¡Â° ÍœÊ– Í¡Â°).

And while we're still talking about beauty let me just point out that Sleeping Dogs looks better and runs wayyy better than Watch Dogs. Sleeping Dogs gets an average of 40 fps on my GT 755M and that's on pretty high settings. This is a perfectly playable framerate and serves as a happy medium between 30 and 60 fps. There a few bugs like sometimes not being able to attach to cover for a few seconds in certain spots or a civilian getting stuck in geometry, but these don't really affect your gameplay experience.

Hong Kong offers a lot to do: you can buy pork buns, other food, get a massage, and do side quests like stealing a car for someone, distracting the cops, or other various activities. Cars offer great arcade-like style, but sometimes it could feel like you're driving on ice which sometimes gets annoying. But there's a mechanic I've never seen in another game: action hijack. This feature, which lets you hijack another vehicle while driving, emphasizes the Asian-action movie vibe this game successfully accomplishes.

While on the topic of action movie, by every mechanic you can see that this is the style the developers were going for. The combat system is wonderfully satisfying and complex in that you can upgrade it to earn new moves and skills such as a leg break or a roundhouse kick. Another mechanic which emphasizes the action-movie vibe is bullet-time. Just like in Max Payne, you can enter slow-motion to do some next-level-human stuff to ultimately wreck your enemies. In Sleeping Dogs this can be triggered by vaulting over cover and aiming or by aiming at enemies while driving. In one side mission, more than 100 motorcyclists were shooting at me consecutively while I was riding shotgun in a car, delivering dope, as gangsters do.

In open world games, the story might be a trivial path for some players for its usual mediocrity. However, in Sleeping Dogs, this is not the case. The plot is surprisingly well-written and interesting. It involves Wei Shen, an undercover cop who is becoming too attached to his gangster role. The story, while not as amazing as, let's say: The Last of Us, is still much better than average and is certainly worth playing through.

Overall, Sleeping Dogs is an open-world game done right. With an interesting story, great use of freedom, challenging yet satisfying combat system, bullet time, and decent driving, you can't go wrong. Sleeping Dogs is a standout in the genre and a game that melds many features in a manner which works.

9.4/10

reviewText: Sleeping Dogs fills an interesting niche in the sandbox crime" genre of video games that seems so popular these days. The game mixes elements of a lot of different open world games together
hoursPlayed: deep storyline that lasts quite a while\n-Solid gameplay
voteText: melee combat is actually pretty fun until the end of the game\n-Game length is acceptable
helpfulPercent: can be longer if you play the DLC and side missions\n-Soundtrack is wonderful; sometimes you just want to sit inside of your car for a little while to let a song end before advancing in the game.\n-Outfits in game are pretty darn cool
votesHelpful:
especially with all the DLC included.
-Just generally fun - I had a hard time putting this game down after getting into the main plot.
-Memorable characters
-Atmospheric environment - even if largely inaccurate.
-It feels like a proper "RPG" in that you actually get into the role of the main character

There are also a lot of smaller issues that really detract from the overall experience. None of these are gamebreaking
votesTotal:
but in hindsight they were pretty annoying.

CONS:
-Upgrade system makes no sense. You hoard melee move upgrades until the end of the game
votesFunny:
only to unlock a powerful god move that makes melee combat irrelevant.
-The concept of "Sandbox" seems lost on the developers; there's nothing to do aside from story missions except run away from the police who are incredibly easy to lose.
-Side missions + DLC are lackluster at best. Especially the "Year of the Snake" DLC. I'd reccomend staying far away from that one if you want to preserve any good memories about the main plot.
-You never need to upgrade your "Face" meter past rank 4 to get the valet; all other elements of that progression tree aren't particularily useful.
-Game ends abruptly. I won't spoil it
commentsCount:
but the last mission just sort of ends very suddenly.
-The frequency at which guns become available after the half-way point is immersion breaking.
-*SHOOTS TIRE* *GAME GOES SLOW MOTION* *SHOOTS OTHER TIRE* *GAME GOES IN SLOW MOTION* ad infintum
-AI is easy. Really easy. You pretty much can't die if you're an average skilled player.
-Graphics options are too limiting
column16:
especially for a "definitive" edition
-Lots and lots of plot holes
-No real villain except "Generic Hong Kong Triad Boss #40"
-Your best friend dies ;-; RIP

Despite all this
column17: I still have to reccomend the game. Comparing all its flaws and its benefits
column18: Sleeping Dogs is truly a fun game deserving of praise. There are issues
column19: but they are acceptable - no game is free of flaws. I wish I had bought the base game when it was out
column20: as a lot of the DLC made the game a heck of a lot less fun with the ease at which you obtain things. I did a single run through playing only small amounts of the side content
column21: and it took me around 20 hours.\n\nI paid 10$USD for this game during the 2014 Steam Winter Sale."

reviewText:
I really want to love this game bc the combat has so much potential. There's just a couple glaring defects that makes this game unplayable for me.

First, its openworld like a GTA, but the camera angles are atroshish!!! So trying to look at any one object in the game is frustrating. Which makes me not want to explore the world too much.

Second, the game clearly puts a premium on careful driving and rewards you for being careful every chance it gets. Once you understand this your fine. But the driving isnt all that fluid, its second rate to a GTA or even a Saints Row 3 or 4.

Third, the combat, admittedly there is a lot to like here with all the combos. Think recent batman games, except the controls aren't as tight, so if you're in the middle of one move and someone tries to hit you they WILL hit you bc you can't couter in the middle of a move. But the big thing with the combat is YOU WILL DIE. Like recent Final Fantasy games where 1 out of every 10 fights or so you would run into something you'd never seen before and get killed by it. The same thing happens here to.

Graphics are great.
Story I hear is good to.
But as much as I want to, I just can't look past the gameplay.

reviewText:
Honestly, I was expecting way more story than this, the DLC's aren't really much and that ending is just kinda dumb.
the story felt obvious though I can put that aside, I wish I could have had a choice to be a gangster or a under cover cop so we could have an actual gang/cop war on the hong kong streets which would be awesome.

Pros:

- Combat is effective

- driving is great, shooting is alright

- me feeling like a badass achieved

- story starts out at a goof parkour service

Cons:

- story is lacking, short and obvious

- Parkour doesn't feel as smooth as I thought it would be

- combat feels like a batman knock off mechanic, though it could have improved

- you can't buy guns (I know it's not GTA but really man?)

-Wei Shen has a problem around raymond quite a lot which wasn't really needed (this is my con)

I'd say that a few plays wouldn't hurt, it can be a sort of guilty pleasure being a undercover cop, I'd only reccomend to those fans of undercover honk kong movies and those who like GTA.

But if you want a spin, I'd take it now before the midweek madness ends cause it's worth at least one play.

reviewText: One of the best GTA-style games I've played. Hong Kong oozes atmosphere and character, and everywhere you look is another homage to Hong Kong action flicks. The combat hits the exact right level of complexity and difficulty, and the city is fun to traverse. Plenty of collectables that give rewards for grabbing them, and show up on the minimap when you finish certain missions (I have a pet peeve of games with lots of collectables but no proper way to track them down). Wei Shen is a likeable protagonist, and the story is great. The DLCs are also pretty well done. Really wish there was more!
